English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course encourages students to expand and practice intensive and extensive reading using a variety of authentic texts in-order to acquire high-level reading skills. The course allows students to work on making interpersonal connections, prediction, identifying the main idea and using semantic clues through vocabulary. The habit of extensive reading in and out of class and  the development of critical thinking skills based on the synthesis, analysis and evaluation of knowledge is also promoted.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand different aspects of reading using authentic readings pieces such as newspapers, magazines, reviews and academic writings by identifying context.
Use high-level reading skills such as making interpersonal links, predicting and identifying main ideas.
Think using critical skills through the synthesis, analysis and evaluation of knowledge.
Use semantic clues and guess words and vocabulary from context to ease reading.
Identify texts that can be read independently at student's leisure.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses on the skill of writing in english. It will look at the rhetoric structure of the paragraph. Also, the course will focus on writing for comparison, discussion and narration. Summary writing, interpretation and review will be practiced through the analysis of literary works both visual and textual. The differences between formal and informal letter writing will be worked on with focus on the appropriate functional language.
course_learning_outcomes: Prepare an outline and write a paragraph  using a recognised rhetorical structure.
Express themselves in the written form through the medium of description, comparison, discussion and narration.
Write a summary using the appropriate rhetorical structure.
Analyse literary work (ie film, short story) inorder to write a commentary, summary or review.
Write formal and informal letters as appropriate.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses on Listening and Pronunciation skills. The students will use authentic listening and speaking materials taken from a variety of contexts to analyze and work on their pronunciation skills. There will also awareness raising activities for the fundamentals of english pronunciation including individual sounds, intonation, word and sentence stress at both sentence and word level.
course_learning_outcomes: Indentify different rhetorics in oral texts.
Follow and undertand a variety of authentic listening texts.
Analyse and respond critically to authentic listening texts.
Identify the basic concepts surrounding the skill of pronunciation.
Show awareness of pronunciation strategies such as intonation, sentence and word stress, and individual sounds.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses on developing student’s verbal communication skills. Through discussion, presentations, and conversational dialogue students practice speaking and listening comprehension skills whilst being exposed to authentic and contemporary verbal, visual and audio material as models.
course_learning_outcomes: Recognise different varieties of the speaking rhetoric.
Converse spontaneously and informally with peers putting forward opinions and offering responses.
Present a topic previously researched and prepared with a degree of confidence.
Take part in discussions on a semi-academic level with peers.
Back up their opinions and ideas with support.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Word and sentence structure of English; simple, embedded and complex sentence structures; tense, aspect, modality, voice and contextual uses of these are handled.
course_learning_outcomes: Define English grammar terms.
Illustrate English grammar structures with examples that they find in various corpora or on their own.
Examine various structures of English.
Question prescriptive rules of grammar.
Gain an understanding of the role of English grammar in creating written and oral texts.
Discuss practical use of  knowledge of English grammar in teaching.
Acquire an understanding of variation in language use and its effects on the structure of English.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Basic concepts related to education and teaching; goals and function of education; relationship of education to other sciences and fields; legal, social, cultural, historical, political, economic, philosophical and psychological bases of education; methodology of educational science; classroom and school as an educational place; teaching profession and recent developments in teacher education; educational trends in the 21st century.
course_learning_outcomes: Recognize basic concepts of education.
Explain theoretical basics of education.
Recognize the teaching profession and the qualifications of the teachers
Recognize the attributes of teacher education.
Analyze the tendencies in educational sciences.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description:
Basic concepts in sociology: Society, social structure, social fact, social phenomena etc;
the leading names in sociology (İbn-i Haldun, A. Comte, K. Marx, E. Durkheim, M. Weber etc.) and their view of education; education in terms of major sociological theories (functionalist theory, symbolic interaction theory, conflict theory, critical theory, social phenomenology, ethnomethodology); social processes (socialization, social stratification, social mobility, social change etc.) and education; social institutions (family, religion, economy, politics) and education; the development of sociology and educational sociology in Turkey (Ziya Gökalp, İsmail Hakkı Baltacıoğlu, Nurettin Topçu, Mümtaz Turhan etc.); culture and education; school as a social, cultural and moral system and community.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain basic concepts in sociology of education and the historical development of the field
Compare various theories in sociology of education
Assess social functions of education and schools
Assess cultural, political and economical foundations in education
Employ sociological perspectives to understand schools and education systems

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: HTR 211, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims teaching some terms like social science, history, revolution, counter-revolution, coups d’etat, state, political power, authority, law, rights etc. The module also aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman society, which is important to understand the conditions of Turkish Revolution. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To discuss some terms like "social science", "history", "revolution", "coups d'etat", "state", "political power", "authority", "law", "rights" etc.
To understand what the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman Empire was.
To understand the differences between Ottoman land formation and feudalism.
To understand what Ottoman modernization was.
To discuss what Ottoman modernization was.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The aim of this course is to enlighten the students about basic information technologies, computer systems, basic concepts about software and hardware, operating system concepts, file management, utility programs (third party software), word processing programs, calculation / table / graphics programs, presentation programs, desktop publishing, web design, use of internet in education, communication and collaboration technologies, safe internet use, information ethics and copyrights.
course_learning_outcomes: Define problem solving concepts and approaches

Define computer systems, basic concepts about software and hardware, operating
system concepts
Use some utility programs such as Word, Excel, Power Point
Use internet safely
Use some of the desktop publishing and web design programs

English Language Teacher Education.course_description:
Historical development of the Turkish language; phonetics/morphology/syntax
Literary language and its features ; Written and oral expression 
Perspective in composition; types of written expression (explanatory, argumentative, descriptive, narrative) Features of textuality (consistency, purpose, admissibility, contingency, informative, intertextuality)
course_learning_outcomes: Developing of Turkish spelling rules and punctuation on texts;
Comprehensive readings on articles; Practice of writing articles.
Have an broad perspective how to bear language; Approaches about Turkish Language historical processes (linguistic main properties)
Development of Turkish philological and literary approaches and practice on texts;
Reach a basic level to discipline of written expression

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: This course works on understanding and identifying inference using deductive and inductive methods and focusses on reading between the lines. This is done by examining the information in the reading texts, understanding direct and indirect ways of expression, methophoric and literal meanings; written and verbal expression of opinion on a reading text; and by understanding that the intended meaning of the author and the meaning that the reader infers may be different.
course_learning_outcomes: Critically analyse higher level reading texts.
Understand the term inference and identify examples using deductive and inductive methods.
Distinguish between direct and indirect expression.
Distinguish intended and hidden messages from literal meaning.
Recognize metaphor, simile and other rhetorical devices.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses on the skills reading for writing and writing for reading through the process of writing essays and reports. Awareness will be raised on the stages of process and product writing, drafting, expansion, self and peer-evaluation and self and peer-editing.
course_learning_outcomes: Identify the differences in the rhetoric structure of report and essay writing.
Plan, prepare and draft an essay.
Plan, prepare and draft a report.
Self-evaluate and self-edit own written work.
Peer-evaluate and peer-edit another’s written work.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses on listening skills such as note-taking, prediction, getting specific and detailed information, getting meaning from context and contextualization. It also pays attention to pronunciation skills with an introduction to regional phonetics by using authentic listening materials such as interviews, films, songs, conferences, TV programs to highlight the variations in English accents.
course_learning_outcomes: Take notes effectively when listening to authentic oral texts.
Interpret and analyze oral texts in-order to make assumptions regarding meaning from context.
Make predictions regarding the content of oral texts,
Identify specific and detailed information.
Appreciate the expansive variety in english accents and some of the phonetic differences.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course focusses of developing and advancing student’s verbal communication skills. Through further development of self expression of feelings and thoughts through interviews, presentations and discussions student’s develop  advanced spoken and comprehension skills by an introduction and application of techniques and strategies.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand and interpret oral techniques and strategies used by native speakers.
Apply oral techniques and strategies where appropriate in discussion at a semi-academic level.
Present a topic previously researched and prepared with a reasonable degree of self-confidence.
Briefly give a monologue/presentation on a topic with minimal preparation.
Prepare for and conduct an interview using effective questioning techniques.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Basic concepts of psychology and educational psychology; research methods in educational psychology; development theories, development areas and processes; individual differences in development; basic concepts related to learning; factors that effect learning; learning theories within the context of education-learning stages; motivation during learning.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain the meaning, scope and functions of concepts of education and psychology.
Explain the fundamental concepts of development.
Discuss the characteristics of physical development according to developmental periods.
Analyze personality development in the framework of various theories.
Discuss learning in terms of different theories.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Basic concepts of philosophy; philosophy of existence, knowledge, morality/values and education; basic philosophical trends (idealism, realism, naturalism, empricism, rationalism, pragmatism, existentialism, analytical philosophy) and education; educational philosophy and education trends: prennialism, essentialism, progressivism, existentialist education; critical/radical education; philosophers’s views on education in the Islamic world and the west (Plato, Aristotle, Socrates, J. Dewey, Ibn-i Sina, Farabi, J.J. Rousseaus etc.); human nature, individual differences and education, education from the perspective of some political and economic ideologies, philosophical trends and education during the modernization of Turkey; philosophical bases of Turkish education system.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain the concepts related to general and educational philosophy.
Explain function and types of philosophy and relation between philosophy and social institutes.
Explain basic and educational philosophies.
Analyze main and educational philosophies.
Evaluate syllabus and process of educational administration in terms of main and educational philosophies.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: HTR 112, which is core course, aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the conditions of Turkish national war and Turkish revolution and foundation of Modern Turkish Republic. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To understand the reasons of the Turkish National War, to define the Turkish National War.
To compare Sevres Treaty and Lozan Treaty.
To understand and define the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To understand political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To discuss political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The course aims to improve the students’ academic communication and research skills through academic writing and presentations. Students prepare a report for methodological research and engage in theoretical and practical training in library research, methods of research, and reaching sources. The main assignment of the course is the preparation of a scientific article and its presentation. The students are also expected to prepare questions for a public survey, carry out an interview, and take notes and write reports on different types of texts.
course_learning_outcomes:
Upon the successful completion of this course the student will be able to:
- formulate a number of questions for a public survey;
- apply questionnaires and interpret preferences;
- record interviews and impressions;
- evaluate findings of the field research;
- assemble sources and results of field studies;
- compose ideas in an academic manner;
- report on the findings of the research project.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: The cultural history of the English literature, American literature and the literature of which original language is English; basic terminology and techniques used in text analysis; major text types; important periods; the content and the style of works such as short story, poem, theater play and novel of various genres of periods; contributions of literature to the understanding of life; a critical review of texts and literary arts
course_learning_outcomes: List the literary characters from Chaucer to Milton.
Discuss the prominent works by the authors of the era.
Compare and contrast the literary  movements of the era.
Reflect on the literary text of the period.
Present oral and written materials in class based on literary texts.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Meaning of learning and teaching English; the purpose and basic principles of teaching English; the history of teaching English; reflection of teaching and learning approaches to English teaching; basic skills in teaching English; examples of in-class practice; current trends and problems in teaching English; components of an effective English language teaching; social, teaching English from social, cultural and economic points of view.
course_learning_outcomes: List main approaches to foreign language teaching.
Differentiate between different methods used by different approaches to language teaching.
Construct their own eclectic method for their learners’ characteristics.
Differentiate between direct and indirect language teaching methods.
Select the most appropriate language teaching tecniques and methods according to level, aptitude and age of learners.
Present language teaching materials prepared for different approaches.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description:
Basic concepts of linguistic analysis; awareness-raising, the error analysis of language learners, case study and comparative analysis of mother tongue and foreign language
concepts related to nature, structure and use; language components as a system; linguistic
attainment and production, sub-branches of linguistics, types of grammar, language universals, linguistic creativity, linguistic arbitrariness, sign languages, artificial language and communication between living things; brain and language, lateralization and handedness, language
evolution, functioning models of human language, language use, and research on language disorders (eg. timed listening test, divided brain, WADA test); phonetics, acoustics, phonetics, speech organs, phonetics, vowels and consonants, international phonetics alphabet; phonetics, voice samples, analogy, incompatibility, binding, consonant letter clusters, silent letters, parts, emphasis and melody; semantics, analysis of meaning components, semantic relations, semantic relation, meaning and referencing and coordination.
course_learning_outcomes: Analyze linguistic data from various languages.
Compare human language with various communication tools (or other species).
Define basic linguistic terms.
Relate their linguistic knowledge to everyday use of language.
Illustrate basic linguistics points with examples from a language that they can speak.
Compare various language structures and typologically similar or different languages.
Question basic ideas related to language.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Analysis and discussion of texts selected from the field of English language education, summarizing and writing reports about them. Comparison of texts on the same topic with different points of view and creation of original texts with one's own opinion.
course_learning_outcomes: Summarize basic texts in education and English language.
Outline basic points in a text or media (such as documentary films).
Evaluate basic ideas and debate topics in language and education.
Present their point of view on topics discussed in class in short essays or in speech in front of an audience.
Compare one's own ideas to others' ideas and evaluate them.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Information technology in education; classification of teaching process and instructional technologies; theoretical approaches to instructional technologies; new orientations in learning approaches; current literacy types; instructional technologies as tools and materials; design of instructional materials; designing thematic teaching materials; creating object-specific object warehouse, teaching material evaluation criteria.
course_learning_outcomes: Generate course material using various technology.
Adapt material development and language testing knowledge to generate computer based language teaching.
Show interest in new technologies in the field of ELT.
Encourage language learners to learn through technology.
Use rubrics to evaluate technology tools.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Basic concepts pertaining to principles and methods of instruction; teaching-learning principles, models, strategies, methods and techniques; instructional objective and goal development; instructional content adaptation & adoption; instructional materials; instructional planning and lesson plans; instructional theories and approaches; success in effective schooling; in-class learning evaluation
course_learning_outcomes: Analyse the curriculum development process.
Arrange a learner centered teaching- learning process
Explain teaching principles.
Analyse different learning approaches.
Plan instructional activities efficiently.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description:
Authors and works from different periods of English literature, Amerikan literature and the literature of which original language is English; the periods and basic movements of the written literature in English
basic concepts, terms, techniques in these literatures using sample texts; literary, philosophical
and scientific movements.
course_learning_outcomes: List the literary characters in the 19th and 20th century.
Discuss the prominent works by the authors of the era.
Compare and contrast the literary  movements of the era.
Reflect on the literary text of the period.
Present oral and written materials in class based on literary texts.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description: Basic concepts of curricula; evolution of English language teaching curricula; approach, content and target skills of the contemporary English language teaching curriculum; higher- and lower-level learning areas; limitations and distribution of learning objectives across grades, and their relationship with other courses; the relationship among English language teaching curricula across different grades; methods, techniques, equipment and materials; measurement and evaluation approach; teacher qualifications/competencies.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain basic concepts of curricula.
Explain evolution of English language teaching curricula.
Discuss limitations and distribution of learning objectives across grades, and their relationship with other courses.
Explain methods, techniques, equipment and materials used in language teaching.
Evaluate measurement approaches.

English Language Teacher Education.course_description:

English Language and Literature.course_description: This is a Fall semester course that will be focusing on the following questions (and many others): What is language? What is not language? How do you know whether you know a language? What is the origin of languages? Is language unique to human species? Why are there many languages? Where do they come from? How are they related? Are some languages simpler than others? Can animals learn and speak human languages? Can thoughts exist without language? What happens in our brain when we speak or listen to languages spoken around us. How do we acquire language? Why and how do we lose language? In this course we will discover languages studying their structure: Structure of words, structure of sentences and the structure of their phonological representation.  We will also discuss topics such as the meaning of words and sentences.

English Language and Literature.course_description: The objective of this course is to provide a comprehensive survey of Britain and its literary heritage within a historical framework. English Language and Literature.course_description:
This course offers a survey of English literature from the Restoration Period through the twentieth century, with an emphasis on fiction, drama, and poetry within their historical contexts. We will examine how writers over more than three centuries responded to significant historical and cultural developments, including imperialism, industrialism, and urbanization.

In addition to gaining familiarity with literary history, we will engage with critical issues that have shaped the social and cultural landscape of seventeenth, eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth-century Britain. The course readings are intended to be representative rather than exhaustive. Lectures will address the formation of the literary canon and discuss the rationale behind the selection of specific texts over others.

English Language and Literature.course_description: In our discussions of American literature from the colonial period to the present, we will consider questions such as: How does the nation come to being through literature? That is, what was important to them and why? How do writers experiment with fiction and question the ideals of heroism, equality, and democracy? How do minority writers challenge the hegemony of white-male-heterosexual American identity? Variety of texts will show us complexity and plurality of the multiethnic American society.

English Language and Literature.course_description:
Near the end of the nineteenth century and in the early twentieth century, the traditional concept of humanity was perceived as ending, giving way to something unknown. In an essay devoted to Charles Baudelaire written in 1913, Paul Verlaine described Baudelaire, a pivotal figure in these movements, as epitomizing the essence of modern man—shaped by the excesses of civilization, with heightened senses, and a complex mind. As another prominent figure of the modernist movement, James Joyce, through his character in “The Dead”, referred to this period as a “thought-tormented age”. Throughout this time of unprecedented upheaval, writers sought new themes, emotions, and experimental forms to interpret and challenge their unfamiliar and disorienting new world. Accordingly, this course examines the relationship between modernity and narrative as explored in the works of the ‘Modernist’ writers and we will explore this crisis of humanity from the late nineteenth century, marked by a sense of exhaustion and foreboding, into the tumultuous twentieth century. We will examine the selected texts as explorations into the unknown, efforts to break away from outdated conventions and discover new forms of intensity, knowledge, love, and redemption. 
Some guiding questions include: How did these narratives present life experienced as what Hardy called ‘the ache of the modern’? How was narrative transformed under the pressures to adequately express such experience? How did the ‘modernist’ novel both transmit and contest ‘modernity’?
course_learning_outcomes: They can list and describe significant novels published in English literature between 1890 and 1950, which were later considered part of the modernist literary movement.
They can interpret the relationship between the novels written in the specified period and modernity in light of historical, social, political, and economic backgrounds.
They can analyze the novels written in the specified period using relevant concepts and terms in the context of literary and artistic debates and ideas brought about by modernity.
They can understand the deep relationship between modernist literature and art.
They can perform close readings of the selected novels and write literary criticism.
They can find critiques published about the selected novels during the period they were written and organize their thoughts and present them.

History.course_description: This course is the first of a two-semester overview of global history that examines pivotal encounters, exchanges, and conflicts between cultures and civilizations that profoundly influenced the course of human history. We selectively cover the various regions of Asia, Africa, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas while looking at major global processes such as migration, trade and the spread of religion. These global processes are contextualized within major historical developments such as the formation and dissolution of states and empires. HIST 161 begins with ancient trade networks of the Fertile Crescent to the spread of monotheism in late antiquity and the early Middle Ages, through Columbus' arrival in the Americas in 1492. HIST 162 continues from the 16th century until the Second World War, covering major developments including the rise of the Atlantic trade system, industrialization, modernization, the emergence of the nation-states, colonialism, the Russian revolution and the rise of fascism.
course_learning_outcomes: On successful completion of this course students should be able to examine interconnections and divergence throughout world history
On successful completion of this course students should be able to explain how trans-regional crossings of ideas, goods, and peoples produced transformations and conflicts
On successful completion of this course students should be able to exemplify how the recurring efforts of people to cross religious, political, and cultural borders brought the world together
On successful completion of this course students should be able to describe changes in power arrangements within and between regions
On successful completion of this course students should be able to understand which parts of the world and regional groups benefited from integration and which resisted

During the course, students are introduced to various primary and secondary sources in order to develop their research skills.

History.course_description: This course covers a time span from 1300 to1800. By doing so, it analyzes the Ottoman Empire as an early-modern polity with its specific institutions. The course starts with the controversial historiographical question of the “rise of the Ottoman Empire” on the legacy of the other cultures in Anatolia. It looks at related questions while discussing imperial consolidation; for example, the construction of Istanbul, the imperial capital, based on the legacy of Constantinople. In addition to these primary discussions, the course analyzes the provincial administration of the empire on the basis of a feudal economy, legal structure of the empire, the relationship of different religious groups with each other as well as with the imperial administration, and different administrative and reactionary techniques of dissent throughout the Empire. Finally, the course explores in detail the dynamics of social and economic transformation that took place in the 17th and 18th centuries.
course_learning_outcomes: Students will have an introductory knowledge on the important issues and discussions on the early-modern Ottoman Empire.
Students will be able to situate the Ottoman Empire in world history
Students will understand and analyze the commonalities of the Ottoman Empire with the previous polities in Anatolia, the most important of which are the Byzantine Empire and the Seljuk dynasty.
Students will explore economic, administrative, legal and social structure of the Empire.
Students will have an awareness of the plurality of social and religious groups and have an idea about the lives of minority groups such as the non-Muslims, women and various dissenters.
Students will analyze economic, social and political transformation that changed the structure of the Empire in many inevitable ways in the 17th and 18th centuries

History.course_description: The primary subject of this course is the major historiographical trends in European-Mediterranean history from ancient to post-modern times. The course includes an overview of the history of the historiography as well as the major methodological schools and developments that influence current historical debates. It starts with the question of when does history begin to be history and explores how the idea of history has developed and changed during different historical periods from ancient to medieval, medieval to Renaissance, and finally modernity to post-modernity. The Enlightenment, historicism, positivism, historical materialism, development of social sciences, post-structuralism and post-modernism are all explored in this course with respect to their influences on historical practice and writing.

History.course_description: This course is basically a survey of European economic history, and aims to introduce the students to the main discussions about European economic development. In this respect, some of the major questions that will be addressed are: was European economic development unique? Can we delineate transitional phases from the middle ages to early modernity, and later to capitalism? What is the relationship between colonialism and industrialization? How can we interpret the first globalization phase in the 19th century, and compare it to the globalization of the late 20th century? Apart from these themes that are discussed chronologically, another aim of the course is to engage in a critical reflection on economic history. Therefore, we have to reflect critically on the following assumptions and questions: Where is Europe? What is the most appropriate unit of analysis to study economic history? Is it possible to delineate the economic realm as separate from political, social, military, or cultural realms? How can we compare European economic history to the economic history of other parts of the world?

Their life styles changed considerably parallel to the growth of urbanization: the development of the guilds and their transformation into trade-unions, changes in agriculture and their repercussions on peasantry, belief systems and folk practices as well as gender issues are among the topics to be studied.

History.course_description: The aim and the purpose of the course: There are different ways to approach specific methodologies for the writing of history. Among these perspectives, the emphasis of this course will be on comparative historical sociology and global history, for a couple of reasons. Even though comparative historical sociology is usually considered to be a subfield of sociology, its general approach, and specific methodologies employed by the historical sociologists are historically grounded. These characteristics allow historians to have a constructive dialogue with another discipline that they generally avoid. Second, the comparative dimension is crucial for historians to think outside of their specializations. This is especially important for the historiographical traditions that attribute some kind of uniqueness to their historical trajectories—both in the West and the rest of the world. Thirdly, comparative historical sociology is interested in very big questions about the dynamics of the modern age, and problematizes many of the feature of the modern world—from the emergence of modern nation-state, to the construction of modern identities; this approach will be immensely helpful for historians to avoid ahistorical approaches and narratives. Finally, even though it is taken for granted that we have been living in a globalized world, thinking history globally requires a good deal of critical reflection, and concomitantly, the field of global history has produced specific approaches and methodologies. Historians should have a good understanding of this diversity.
course_learning_outcomes: learn major topics in historical sociology
learn major approaches to global history
compare a historiography based on nation-states with global history and comparative sociology
reflect on why history matters for the present
apply the methods and approaches of global history and historical sociology to the topics of research

History.course_description: This course will introduce you to some of the basic themes of Ottoman social history and the various actors that played diverse functions in the Ottoman society. The emphasis will be on the sultans’ ‘ordinary’ subjects, who get little attention in most other courses and also in the scholarship. Although this course does not have a strong chronological focus, it still moves along the time line of Ottoman history. One of the aims of this purposefully loose chronology is to encourage you to consider the dynamism of Ottoman social structure. In other words, this course aims to encourage you to think over the ways how some actors who were once very important disappeared in time and replaced by new actors. In this course, we will focus on different social groups, their functions, interrelations, and transformations. Finally, we will discuss whether at any time in history, an entity called the “Ottoman society” had ever existed or not.

History.course_description:
The aim of the course is to introduce the students to the field of comparative and historical sociology. This field is usually considered a sub-field in the discipline of sociology, but historians have a lot to learn from sociology, and comparative perspectives. In this respect, there will be two main emphases throughout this term: how to come to grips with the big questions, and how to think about the comparison. The big questions include the debates about the uniqueness of Western modernity, the transition from feudalism to capitalism, the emergence of the modern states, and the dynamics of the revolutions.  The comparative component is more theoretical and includes such issues as To what extent is historical sociology different from history and sociology? What is the relationship between agency and structure? What is the most appropriate unit of analysis in order to compare different socio-political regimes? 

As an upper-level course that aims to deal with big questions and comparisons, it requires intensive reading and critical reflection on the material.

Ask “big questions” about historical transformation

Develop a critical perspective on the importance the institutions

History.course_description: The primary subject of this course is the major historiographical trends in European-Mediterranean history from ancient to post-modern times. The course includes an overview of the history of the historiography as well as the major methodological schools and developments that influence current historical debates. It starts with the question of when does history begin to be history and explores how the idea of history has developed and changed during different historical periods from ancient to medieval, medieval to Renaissance, and finally modernity to post-modernity. The Enlightenment, historicism, positivism, historical materialism, development of social sciences, post-structuralism and post-modernism are all explored in this course with respect to their influences on historical practice and writing.

History.course_description: This course covers a time span from 1300 to1800. By doing so, it analyzes the Ottoman Empire as an early-modern polity with its specific institutions. The course starts with the controversial historiographical question of the “rise of the Ottoman Empire” on the legacy of the other cultures in Anatolia. It looks at related questions while discussing imperial consolidation; for example, the construction of Istanbul, the imperial capital, based on the legacy of Constantinople. In addition to these primary discussions, the course analyzes the provincial administration of the empire on the basis of a feudal economy, legal structure of the empire, the relationship of different religious groups with each other as well as with the imperial administration, and different administrative and reactionary techniques of dissent throughout the Empire. Finally, the course explores in detail the dynamics of social and economic transformation that took place in the 17th and 18th centuries.

The course will examine political, economic and diplomatic developments in the World order  in the period 1914-1989  from a global perspective. In addition to three major conflicts of the 20th century (World War I, World War II, and the Cold War), the course will analyze the economic and political problems of the interwar and the post-Cold War periods, as well as anti-systemic movements such as the Non-Aligned Movement and 1968.
course_learning_outcomes: Develop an understanding of the key issues of the 20th century history;
Ascertain the elements of change and continuity in World politics and diplomacy into the 21st century.
Approach analytically and critically to the human experience in the 20th century.
be informed on the history of the 20th century Asia, which is becoming important in contemporary world politics.
be acquainted with the problems of contemporary world politics that is rooted in the 20th century.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course gives a broad outline of the basic structures and topics of Europeanization, European culture and identity as they have been constructed throughout history. It is an introduction to the different historical constructions of 'Europe' with their ramifications for the global order from the early Middle Ages to our times. The course also sheds light on the notions of feudalism, democratization and enlightenment, which are essential componenets of the European political culture.
course_learning_outcomes: Students will be able to understand the major debates on European identity in their historicity;
Students will be able to relate these debates to major European philosophers who have in history articulated views on 'Europe', Europeanization and a 'European' political order;
Students will be able to explain the ways in which different 'Europe's in history led in turn to certain visions of the "Orient" , which also had significant political and economic ramifications;
Students will be able to analyse how current debates on Europeanization and European identity relate to the EU as a political entity;
The students are also expected to generate an interculturalist approach in understanding those with different ethnic, cultural and religious backgrounds.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course is designed to provide an understanding of the institutions, functioning and the main policies of the European Union. The course also focuses on the ways in which the accession process has transformed the governmental institutions, central-local relations, political parties, NGOs and political life in the member states of the EU.
course_learning_outcomes: Students will be able to understand the roles of the European Commission, Council, the European Parliament and the European Court of Justice in the integration process.
Students will be able to apply different theoretical perspectives to the political debates discussed in class.
Students will be able to identify the main theoretical approaches to EU integration and their strengths and weaknesses.
Students will acquire sufficient knowledge on selected policies of the EU.
Students will be able to apply their knowledge of the theories of European integration to EU policies and policy-making.

European Union Studies.course_description: The primary aim of this course is to provide students with a thorough understanding of the basic rules concerning substantive EU economic law, the regulation of the internal market as well as its external trade policy through an interactive approach. The purpose of the course is two-fold: first, to provide a sound introduction to the basic features of the law applicable to internal and external regulation of the EU's economic activities, and second, to explore the operation of selected aspects of EU law in practice in the contemporary international legal and economic context. These objectives will be achieved by analyzing the case law of the Court of Justice of the EU and related international courts and key primary and secondary legislation with regard to the liberalization of internal trade and the creation of common commercial policy through harmonization of its external trade practices. The primary skills objectives of this course are to develop critical analysis and argument, together with legal problem-solving and skills of independent study.
course_learning_outcomes: Identify and understand legal rationale for the internal market as well as the main obstacles to its  implementation
Distinguish the basic types of economic integration (i.e. free trade area; customs union; internal market) in wider global trading system
Understand and describe the concept of free movement of goods, services, persons and capital and elaborate on its evolution in comparison with the regulation of multilateral trade relations
Observe similarities and differences between the free movement regulations in the EU internal market and the liberalisation of trade in the multilateral trade system.
Notice the impact of free movement regulation on the other EU policies that are linked to the internal market.

European Union Studies.course_description: The study of the political systems in a comparative framework enables students and scholars develop insight into the functioning of the regime and institutions in a country with a new perspective. This course introduces the basic concepts, institutions, and discussions of comparative politics, which will later be applied on the country cases in IR 302.
course_learning_outcomes: describe the basic concepts of International Relations and Political Science with comparative method
compare political systems and institutions
analyze the relation between the political institutions and democratic consolidation
analyze the impact of government systems and electoral institutions on the political systems
develop an analytical approach to political behavior from a comparative perspective

European Union Studies.course_description: This course aims to examine the basic concepts and topics of international law, providing a basis for the discussion of current international issues. Within this framework, sources of international law, subjects of international law and jurisdiction are covered.
course_learning_outcomes: list and define sources of international law.
explain how sources of international law are formed.
explain the relationship between international law and domestic law.
identify which international legal rules should be applied in a given situation.
list conditions of recognition of states and governments.
identify whether recognition in a given situation is in compliance with international law.
explain different aspects of state jurisdiction.
identify exceptions to state jurisdiction in a given situation.

European Union Studies.course_description: HTR 111, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims teaching some terms like social science, history, revolution, counter-revolution, coups d’etat, state, political power, authority, law, rights etc. The module also aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman society, which is important to understand the conditions of Turkish Revolution. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To discuss some terms like "social science", "history", "revolution", "coups d'etat", "state", "political power", "authority", "law", "rights" etc.
To understand what the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman Empire was
To understand the differences between Ottoman land formation and feudalism.
To understand what Ottoman modernization was.
To discuss what Ottoman modernization was.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course focuses on comparing the institutional composition of advanced industrialized democracies by building on the themes discussed in IR 101 (Introduction to Politics) and IR 301 (Comparative Politics I). The weeks are divided thematically, however the selection of readings aims to introduce students to the past and current political issues in Western Europe -especially in Britain, France, Germany- and in the USA, Russia, Mexico, China, Iran and Tunisia. The various decision-making institutions of these countries and how different configurations of power work in diverse political contexts will be analyzed. A variety of political party systems will be examined and the institutional, structural and historical causes of these divergent systems will be scrutinized.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand the significant elements of the presidential system in the USA and France.
Analyze the extent to which the parliaments in Britain, the USA, Germany and Russia keep the executive under control.
Compare the constitutional traditions of Britain and the USA.
Examine the party systems of Britain, the USA, France, Germany, and Spain.
Compare proportional representation and first-past-the-post electoral systems
Scrutinize how and why the single party regimes of Italy, Mexico, and Japan came to power.
Describe the basic institutional elements of the competitive authoritarian system in Russia.
Familiarize with the Indian and Chinese political systems' main frameworks.

European Union Studies.course_description: The aim of this course is to introduce the student to some areas of international law such as state responsibility, international dispute settlement and prohibition on the use of force and demonstrate how general principles of international law apply in these areas.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain conditions of state responsibility
Explain different methods of international dispute settlement
Explain the conditions of lawful use of force in international relations
Identify unlawful uses of force in international relations
Explain the principles of international humanitarian law
Define various areas of the sea and explain the jurisdiction of coastal states with regard to these areas

European Union Studies.course_description: HTR 112, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the conditions of Turkish national war and Turkish revolution and foundation of Modern Turkish Republic. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To understand the reasons of the Turkish National War, to define the Turkish National War
To compare Sevres Treaty and Lozan Treaty.
To understand and define the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To understand political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To discuss political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course aims to give students an understanding of diverse range of principal topics and issues of discussion to explore external relations of the European Union (EU). We will cover two main aspects of EU’s external relations: (i) theories and institutions of the EU’s external relations, and (ii) contemporary issues where EU plays a vital role. Topics that will be discussed in the course include the Eurozone financial crisis, EU-Russia energy dynamics, EU leadership in international climate policy, Turkey’s accession, the “Arab Spring”, the crisis in Ukraine, "Refugee Crisis", Iran Nuclear Programme and Brexit.
course_learning_outcomes: have comprehensive understanding of the EU’s role in international relations.
demonstrate a working knowledge of the EU, the processes of international relations and contemporary issues.
identify and evaluate the institutions of the EU in the realm of external relations.
analyze contemporary issues and the EU’s role in the international system in the light of the main theories, models and concepts in EU studies.
evaluate critically EU's activities and their impact in the world arena.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course aims to provide a general framework on the major issues in political economy, and on the interaction between economy, markets, and society. Throughout the course economy is analyzed as an instituted process. The course begins by challenging the mainstream approach, which argues for the detachment of economy from politics, and emphasizes the political nature of the economic sphere. Within this framework, Mercantilism, Liberalism and Marxism are explained as the main approaches. The first major focus of the course is capitalism as a system. The capitalist system is analyzed with its implications both at the domestic and international levels. The second major focus of the course is neo-liberal globalization. Contemporary capitalism and globalization are discussed within the framework of the global crisis and the European and Turkish examples are analysed.
course_learning_outcomes: Have a good understanding of a range of perspectives which seek to explain government industry relations in Europe
Be able to outline historical and contemporary debates on the economic role of the state
A knowledge and understanding of major European economic policy issues from a political science and economics perspective
Understand European Monetary and Fiscal institutions
A more in-depth knowledge of a specific area of economic policy making
Explain the relationship between the EU and the world
Deep analytical understanding of and a systematic treatment of empirical issues related to the evolution of the European political economy
Have improved communication, documentary and research skills

European Union Studies.course_description: This course addresses the fundamental principles of project management, and tools and techniques. These principles are being successfully applied to projects of all sizes and types within the business world. After the review of state-of-the-art issues, students learn techniques that can reinforce project planning and controlling skills, and enrich leadership skills. The phases of the projects as initiation, planning, execution, control and closure are analyzed in systems approach in this course. Topics to cover also include project management as a career, skills and knowledge required by professionals, including decision making and resource allocation appropriate to project phases and integration with other disciplines.
course_learning_outcomes: Use modern techniques for project selection relating them to corporate strategy
Manage the budget, schedule, and quality of projects
Construct the project network, apply CPM and PERT estimating cost and times and recognizing the trade-offs
Assign resources to the tasks in the project
Measure and hedge risks
Communicate effectively with the project team, client and supervisors
Lead or be a member of a project team of diverse individuals
Develop software skills by using MS Project on a project scenario

European Union Studies.course_description: This course aims to give detailed information on EU-supported funds and programmes in the form of grants, loans or tenders including structural funds, Union programmes and pre-accession instrument for candidate countries. Science diplomacy is covered to comprehend the relationships between EU, candidate and other countries. Influence of recent developments in technological, economical, social and political advances on EU funding schemes are reviewed. Types of EU funds along with EU-Turkey fiscal cooperations are discussed to provide an overall perspective on this issue.  Topics such as project management, risk management, writing proposals, project milestones, deliverables and work packages are addressed. Focus will be on the selection criteria for EU projects as well to explain how to succeed in project applications.
course_learning_outcomes: Gain an overall perspective about context, aims and political and historical background of various EU financing schemes and funding programmes.
Discuss the political, social and environmental impacts of EU funding and grants in different contexts such as member, candidate and other countries.
Interpret the influence of recent global developments on the future of EU funding trends.
Understand the details associated with EU and Turkey fiscal cooperations and programmes.

Use EU databases and internet facilities effectively to search for calls and tenders on various EU financing schemes and find out the requirements and principles concerning grants and funding programmes.
Develop proficiencies to comprehend key tasks such as project risk management, preparing proposals for EU funded programmes, projects milestones and work packages.
Analyze the features of TUBITAK funded projects and similarities/differences between EU and TUBITAK supported programmes.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course will introduce the students to the origins, structures and functioning of international organizations. The course will emphasize the role of international organizations in contemporary world politics and their role in the establishment and diffusion of international norms. The EU will be dealt with broadly within the context of global governance, and each week the EU’s role on current issues in world politics will be focused on. The course is being offered as part of the Jean Monnet Chair of the Erasmus+ Programme, funded by the European Union. Dr. Özge Onursal Beşgül will carry out her duty as Jean Monnet Chair, a post entrusted to those faculty members who have expertise in European Union studies within the framework of the Erasmus+ program, between March 1, 2022-February 28, 2025.
course_learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be informed on the role of the international organisations in world politics;
will be acquainted with the United Nations system.
will be able to analyse the historical evolution of the international organisations in relation to the theories of international relations;
will have knowledge of the main regional international organisations and their functioning;
will be able to tackle issues of conflict and cooperation in international relations from different theoretical perspectives.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course provides an overview of the history, the evolving treaty framework, the polical institutions, the decision-making processes and key policies of the European Union.  The course will address the questions related to particular choices of institutional design, policies and enlargement of the European Union in line with preferences and priorities of individual member states and the EU institutions as well as the changing international context.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course the students will be able to state the important turning points in the history of the European integration process;
to explain the evolving treaty framework;
to explain the different institutions of the European Union;
to examine the European integration process through different theoretical outlooks;
to compare the political structures of the EU members and candidates.

European Union Studies.course_description: This course focuses on the developments that led to the end of the Cold War era and the politics of the post-Cold War period. Starting with the last decade of the Soviet Union and the forces that brought about the demise of Leninism in Eastern Europe, the break-up of Yugoslavia is studied as the paradigmatic case of the post-Cold War era. Other issues include the politics of the Middle East, post-Cold War American foreign policy and the pluses and minuses of globalization.

At the end of this course, the students should be able to identify the main issues and trends that effect world politics.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to reflect critically on the salient world political issues of the day.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to distinguish the proper venues through which they can follow salient world political developments.

International Relations.course_description:
After having completed this course, the student will
-become familiar what politics is, how political systems are organized, what the main political institutions of a political system are, how the links between society and politics are established, how political decisions are made, and in general how societies are governed, 
-be able to identify different political systems, their institutions, organizational structure, and their sociological and ideological foundations and compare systems with each other, and classify them

The student can use basic political terms to understand political life.
The student can follow government formation and electoral processes in an informed manner.
The student develops an interest to learn more about national and international politics.
Enumerate the qualities of a democracy
Differentiate democratic and nondemocratic forms of government
solve cases based on his/her political knowledge.

International Relations.course_description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the basic concepts of social sciences.The course has two objectives: (1) to welcome and orient you to your Department and (2) to assist you to develop further the academic skills that are necessary for you to make the most of the university education. Education has three essential elements: to read to learn, to think to understand and to write to express what is learned and understood. We will work on them.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the students have an introductory knowledge on social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students are informed about the main concepts and discussions of social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students can understand different methods in social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students will be able to critically assess issues in social sciences.

International Relations.course_description: This is an introductory microeconomics course. The way economists explain consumer and producer behavior is the main focus of the course.
course_learning_outcomes: Describe firm behavior under different market structures
Find optimal price-quantity policies for firms
Explain the effects of a government intervention to markets
Provide a theoretical explanation for the equilibrium market price of a commodity
Explain the effects of a change in an external factor on markets
Explain the relationship between sustainability, scarcity, and choice in economics, and how limited resources influence decision-making processes.

International Relations.course_description: English for Academic Purposes I is a course designed to develop the academic language and academic skills needed by students in order to be successful in their respective departments. Students will be guided through the various stages of writing, including planning, researching and collecting and organizing information. Students will be working with semi-authentic to authentic academic texts. The course aims to introduce efficient reading strategies to cope with such texts as well as to increase students' confidence and comprehensibility when delivering information in an academic setting. Academic writing, listening, speaking and reading skills development will be emphasized in the course. Additionally, students' skills in test-taking, paraphrasing, summarizing and note-taking will be developed.
course_learning_outcomes: recognize vocabulary and discern meaning from context
approach assessment with a required skill set
apply note-taking strategies for study
summarize a text in a written format
write a report

International Relations.course_description:
The aim of this lecture is to teach any student who has finished its undergraduate studies, to acknowledge and learn the structure and the functionality of the Turkish language, from the perspective of linguistic and thought relation, to implement the skill to use the Turkish language right and effective as a written and spoken expression tool.
By teaching the historical process of the Turkish language, its place in the universal linguistic families, analyzing the important shifts and transformations of the Turkish language, and carefully teaching the sets of dictation, this lecture is set to transpose an overall knowledge and practical skill sets to students.
course_learning_outcomes: Understanding the fundamental concepts of the Turkish language, its historical process, and the ability to reflect these learnings in daily life.

Establishing the skill to understand the main takeaways of this course and further use these capacities to compare the Turkish language with other languages, detecting puzzles and issues within this comparison and address rational responses to such problems.

Learning the structural and conceptual aspects of the Turkish language, improving overall knowledge about the language for better evaluation and analysis, and to attain the ability to do accurate research and rational answers when being questioned about this field.

Learning the unique relationship of the language with other disciplines which will contribute greatly to the intellectual accumulation of the student(s) to use the language with awareness and originality.
To care about the oral and written set of rules of the Turkish language and raising awareness.

International Relations.course_description: This course aims to provide students with a framework for understanding the main issues and concepts of international relations like international anarchy, international system, international organizations, balance of power, gender, war, diplomacy, development, globalization and environment. Lectures and readings will help students analyse traditional and alternative approaches to international relations and their relevance in contemporary global context.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, students are expected to develop a critical understanding of the key concepts and issues of international relations.
At the end of the course, the students will acquire basic knowledge of international relations theories.
At the end of the course, the students will be able to use the theories of international relations.
At the end of the course, the students will be familiar with the current issues of international relations.
At the end of the course, the students should be able compare and contrast the policy prescriptions of traditional and alternative views in tackling current global issues.

course_learning_outcomes: To make students think on basic methodological discussions of social sciences
To develop students' capacity for mathematical thinking necessary for the various issues and problems of social sciences
To teach basic concepts of logic, functions, probability and game theory
To teach the basics of quantitative techniques
To make students familiar with the basic data sets used in social sciences

International Relations.course_description: This is an introductory macroeconomics course. The aim of the course is to teach elementary macroeconomic analysis and its applications. Among the main topics discussed are national income accounting, aggregate demand and supply, unemployment, money and inflation.
course_learning_outcomes: Calculate important macroeconomic economic concepts such a s the CPI or GDP
Explain economic cycles by the theories proposed by different schools of thought in economics
Explain unemployent through the labor market
Explain the effects of fiscal and monetary policies
Explain the relation between important economic concepts such as inflation rate, interest rate, unemployment rate etc

Conceptualizing the written expressions in the Turkish language and acquiring the ability to understand the differences between the types of expression which will contribute to the skill set of the student(s).
Learning the basics of the written expressions, the ability to compare the written expression types and reflect this knowledge into personal work in the future.

Acquiring the ability of originality in thinking and demonstrating and analyzing the literary pieces with critical thinking abilities.

course_learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, the students become capable of reading, interpreting and making sense of the quantitative studies that they read in the social science literature.

International Relations.course_description: The course is designed to provide an introduction to Turkish Politics that aims to familiarize the student with the recent political history of Turkey and to develop a framework for analysis of contemporary Turkish politics.

. The subject of the course covers the modernization process in the late Ottoman period, the establishment of the Turkish Republic, the single-party period, transition to the multi-party system, DP period and the review of political developments and political change until 1960.

Topics to be covered include the paradigms of the social science: methodological traditions (mainly qualitative and quantitative methods) and research designs with various research tools and techniques. The first part of the course will be devoted to lectures and discussions of the research methods. And in the second part, students are expected to conduct their own research projects either individually or as a group.
course_learning_outcomes: The students taking this course will be able to make a critical reflection about the scientific quality of a scholarly work that they read in social science literature
Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be able to write a research proposal on a topic they would like to study
The small field work that the students will participate during the course will provide them an experience about the practice of social research
The students will be able to make critical assessments regarding the research methods used in the texts that they will be reading
The students will have insights about the basic discussions in philosophy of Social Sciences.

International Relations.course_description: The aim of the course is to enable the students to grasp the structure, organization and functioning of the state. The development of constitutionalism and the principles and procedures of constitutional law will also be covered.
course_learning_outcomes: Describe concepts such as constitution, supremacy of constitution, constitutional regime, restriction of state power and separation of powers.
Recognize the structure and functioning of legislative and executing bodies in comparative perspective.
Explain the enactment and implementation of the legal norms the Turkish constitutional system.
Tell the general principles of the Turkish constitutional system.
Define development of the constitutional law in Turkey.
Express making and implementation of the constitutions in Turkey.
Explain the notions of democracy, rule of law, welfare state, human rights, laicism and equality.
Identify the development of righst and freedoms.

International Relations.course_description: The study of the political systems in a comparative framework enables students and scholars develop insight into the functioning of the regime and institutions in a country with a new perspective. This course introduces the basic concepts, institutions, and discussions of comparative politics, which will later be applied on the country cases in IR 302.
course_learning_outcomes: describe the basic concepts of International Relations and Political Science with comparative method
compare political systems and institutions
analyze the relation between the political institutions and democratic consolidation
analyze the impact of government systems and electoral institutions on the political systems
develop an analytical approach to political behavior from a comparative perspective

International Relations.course_description: This course is designed to familiarize students with the contemporary history and politics of international relations. The first part of the course will deal with developments from the end of Cold War until the end of the twentieth century.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the students should be able to possess factual and historical knowledge on the Post-Cold War decade (1990’s).
At the end of this course, the students should be able to critically analyse the trends of transition and transformation in the post-communist countries.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to comprehend the changes and continuities in trans-Atlantic relations after the Cold War.
At the end of this course, the students will be able to follow and interpret current world politics.
At the end of this course, the students will have augmented their report and essay writing skills.
