develop their article analysis skills.
develop their English discussion skills.
develop a basic understanding of the thoughts of major figures in international theory.
think with and against these theorists and use their different perspectives in understanding international relations.
come up with their own positions vis a vis the current challenges of "global politics."
interpret current developments in global politics from different theoretical perspectives
critically evaluate global political analyses in terms of their theoretical underpinnings

International Relations.course_description: This course aims to examine the basic concepts and topics of international law, providing a basis for the discussion of current international issues. Within this framework, sources of international law, subjects of international law and jurisdiction are covered.
course_learning_outcomes: list and define sources of international law.
explain how sources of international law are formed.
explain the relationship between international law and domestic law.
identify which international legal rules should be applied in a given situation.
list conditions of recognition of states and governments.
identify whether recognition in a given situation is in compliance with international law.
explain different aspects of state jurisdiction.
identify exceptions to state jurisdiction in a given situation.

International Relations.course_description: HTR 111, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims teaching some terms like social science, history, revolution, counter-revolution, coups d’etat, state, political power, authority, law, rights etc. The module also aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman society, which is important to understand the conditions of Turkish Revolution. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To discuss some terms like "social science", "history", "revolution", "coups d'etat", "state", "political power", "authority", "law", "rights" etc.
To understand what the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman Empire was
To understand the differences between Ottoman land formation and feudalism.
To understand what Ottoman modernization was.
To discuss what Ottoman modernization was.

International Relations.course_description: This course focuses on comparing the institutional composition of advanced industrialized democracies by building on the themes discussed in IR 101 (Introduction to Politics) and IR 301 (Comparative Politics I). The weeks are divided thematically, however the selection of readings aims to introduce students to the past and current political issues in Western Europe -especially in Britain, France, Germany- and in the USA, Russia, Mexico, China, Iran and Tunisia. The various decision-making institutions of these countries and how different configurations of power work in diverse political contexts will be analyzed. A variety of political party systems will be examined and the institutional, structural and historical causes of these divergent systems will be scrutinized.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand the significant elements of the presidential system in the USA and France.
Analyze the extent to which the parliaments in Britain, the USA, Germany and Russia keep the executive under control.
Compare the constitutional traditions of Britain and the USA.
Examine the party systems of Britain, the USA, France, Germany, and Spain.
Compare proportional representation and first-past-the-post electoral systems
Scrutinize how and why the single party regimes of Italy, Mexico, and Japan came to power.
Describe the basic institutional elements of the competitive authoritarian system in Russia.
Familiarize with the Indian and Chinese political systems' main frameworks.

International Relations.course_description: This course focuses on the developments that led to the end of the Cold War era and the politics of the post-Cold War period. Starting with the last decade of the Soviet Union and the forces that brought about the demise of Leninism in Eastern Europe, the break-up of Yugoslavia is studied as the paradigmatic case of the post-Cold War era. Other issues include the politics of the Middle East, post-Cold War American foreign policy and the pluses and minuses of globalization.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the students should be able to possess factual and historical knowledge on contemporary world politics.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to identify the main issues and trends that effect world politics.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to reflect critically on the salient world political issues of the day.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to distinguish the proper venues through which they can follow salient world political developments.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to follow and comment on world political events over current social media platforms.
develop their presentation skills
develop their article analysis skills.
develop their English discussion skills.

International Relations.course_description: This course will introduce the students to the origins, structures and functioning of international organizations. The course will emphasize the role of international organizations in contemporary world politics and their role in the establishment and diffusion of international norms. The EU will be dealt with broadly within the context of global governance, and each week the EU’s role on current issues in world politics will be focused on. The course is being offered as part of the Jean Monnet Chair of the Erasmus+ Programme, funded by the European Union. Dr. Özge Onursal Beşgül will carry out her duty as Jean Monnet Chair, a post entrusted to those faculty members who have expertise in European Union studies within the framework of the Erasmus+ program, between March 1, 2022-February 28, 2025.
course_learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, the students will be informed on the role of the international organisations in world politics;
will be acquainted with the United Nations system.
will be able to analyse the historical evolution of the international organisations in relation to the theories of international relations;
will have knowledge of the main regional international organisations and their functioning;
will be able to tackle issues of conflict and cooperation in international relations from different theoretical perspectives.

International Relations.course_description: The aim of this course is to introduce the student to some areas of international law such as state responsibility, international dispute settlement and prohibition on the use of force and demonstrate how general principles of international law apply in these areas.
course_learning_outcomes: Explain conditions of state responsibility
Explain different methods of international dispute settlement
Explain the conditions of lawful use of force in international relations
Identify unlawful uses of force in international relations
Explain the principles of international humanitarian law
Define various areas of the sea and explain the jurisdiction of coastal states with regard to these areas

International Relations.course_description: HTR 112, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the conditions of Turkish national war and Turkish revolution and foundation of Modern Turkish Republic. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To understand the reasons of the Turkish National War, to define the Turkish National War
To compare Sevres Treaty and Lozan Treaty.
To understand and define the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To understand political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To discuss political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.

International Relations.course_description: The course will cover the republican period until the US occupation of Iraq in 2003. The lectures will emphasise major developments and discuss their reasons and consequences.
course_learning_outcomes: By the end of this course students will get background information about landmark developments of Turkey's foreign policy decisions taken during the period between 1920 and 2002.
Students would be able to identify the causes and effects of major developments on foreign policy decisions that the course will cover.
Students will understand the domestic political context of these decisions.
Students will understand the international context of these decisions.
Students will able to relate the concerning decisions with the current issues.

International Relations.course_description: The course will cover current issues of Turkey’s foreign policy during the last decade. The lectures will deal with major international developments in the adjacent regions having particular relevance for Turkey's foreign policy agenda. The issues will be analysed through a three - İnternational system, national political and leadership- level analysis.
course_learning_outcomes: By the end of this course students will get information about important Turkish foreign policy decisions taken during the period succeeding 2003.
Students will be able to identify the causes and effects of developments surrounding the issues that the course will cover.
Students will understand the domestic political context of the issues and discuss the implications of the policies pursued by Ankara.
Students will be able to evaluate the background of the concerning decisions and put them into a internal political perspective.
Students will be able relate the concerning decisions to their historical precedents.

International Relations.course_description: This is a follow-up course which picks up where “IR 231 Political and Diplomatic History I” has left off. The course will examine political, economic and diplomatic developments in the World order  in the period 1914-1989  from a global perspective. In addition to three major conflicts of the 20th century (World War I, World War II, and the Cold War), the course will analyze the economic and political problems of the interwar and the post-Cold War periods, as well as anti-systemic movements such as the Non-Aligned Movement and 1968.
course_learning_outcomes: Develop an understanding of the key issues of the 20th century history;
Ascertain the elements of change and continuity in World politics and diplomacy into the 21st century.
Approach analytically and critically to the human experience in the 20th century.
be informed on the history of the 20th century Asia, which is becoming important in contemporary world politics.
be acquainted with the problems of contemporary world politics that is rooted in the 20th century.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description:
After having completed this course, the student will
-become familiar what politics is, how political systems are organized, what the main political institutions of a political system are, how the links between society and politics are established, how political decisions are made, and in general how societies are governed, 
-be able to identify different political systems, their institutions, organizational structure, and their sociological and ideological foundations and compare systems with each other, and classify them
-be able to use political science concepts and taxonomies to analyze and interpret political phenomena.
course_learning_outcomes: The student can become familiar what politics is.
The student can differentiate different political systems.
The student can use basic political terms to understand political life.
The student can follow government formation and electoral processes in an informed manner.
The student develops an interest to learn more about national and international politics.
Enumerate the qualities of a democracy
Differentiate democratic and nondemocratic forms of government
solve cases based on his/her political knowledge.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The purpose of this course is to introduce students to the basic concepts of social sciences.The course has two objectives: (1) to welcome and orient you to your Department and (2) to assist you to develop further the academic skills that are necessary for you to make the most of the university education. Education has three essential elements: to read to learn, to think to understand and to write to express what is learned and understood. We will work on them.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the students have an introductory knowledge on social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students are informed about the main concepts and discussions of social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students can understand different methods in social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students will be able to critically assess issues in social sciences.
At the end of this course, the students will be introduced on the analysis of  politics.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: This is an introductory microeconomics course. The way economists explain consumer and producer behavior is the main focus of the course.
course_learning_outcomes: Describe firm behavior under different market structures
Find optimal price-quantity policies for firms
Explain the effects of a government intervention to markets
Provide a theoretical explanation for the equilibrium market price of a commodity
Explain the effects of a change in an external factor on markets
Explain the relationship between sustainability, scarcity, and choice in economics, and how limited resources influence decision-making processes.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: English for Academic Purposes I is a course designed to develop the academic language and academic skills needed by students in order to be successful in their respective departments. Students will be guided through the various stages of writing, including planning, researching and collecting and organizing information. Students will be working with semi-authentic to authentic academic texts. The course aims to introduce efficient reading strategies to cope with such texts as well as to increase students' confidence and comprehensibility when delivering information in an academic setting. Academic writing, listening, speaking and reading skills development will be emphasized in the course. Additionally, students' skills in test-taking, paraphrasing, summarizing and note-taking will be developed.
course_learning_outcomes: recognize vocabulary and discern meaning from context
approach assessment with a required skill set
apply note-taking strategies for study
summarize a text in a written format
write a report

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description:
The aim of this lecture is to teach any student who has finished its undergraduate studies, to acknowledge and learn the structure and the functionality of the Turkish language, from the perspective of linguistic and thought relation, to implement the skill to use the Turkish language right and effective as a written and spoken expression tool.
By teaching the historical process of the Turkish language, its place in the universal linguistic families, analyzing the important shifts and transformations of the Turkish language, and carefully teaching the sets of dictation, this lecture is set to transpose an overall knowledge and practical skill sets to students.
course_learning_outcomes: Understanding the fundamental concepts of the Turkish language, its historical process, and the ability to reflect these learnings in daily life.

Establishing the skill to understand the main takeaways of this course and further use these capacities to compare the Turkish language with other languages, detecting puzzles and issues within this comparison and address rational responses to such problems.

Learning the structural and conceptual aspects of the Turkish language, improving overall knowledge about the language for better evaluation and analysis, and to attain the ability to do accurate research and rational answers when being questioned about this field.

Learning the unique relationship of the language with other disciplines which will contribute greatly to the intellectual accumulation of the student(s) to use the language with awareness and originality.
To care about the oral and written set of rules of the Turkish language and raising awareness.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: This course aims to provide students with a framework for understanding the main issues and concepts of international relations like international anarchy, international system, international organizations, balance of power, gender, war, diplomacy, development, globalization and environment. Lectures and readings will help students analyse traditional and alternative approaches to international relations and their relevance in contemporary global context.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of the course, students are expected to develop a critical understanding of the key concepts and issues of international relations.
At the end of the course, the students will acquire basic knowledge of international relations theories.
At the end of the course, the students will be able to use the theories of international relations.
At the end of the course, the students will be familiar with the current issues of international relations.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The purpose of this course is to introduce the basic analytical tools and techniques used in social sciences.
course_learning_outcomes: To make students think on basic methodological discussions of social sciences
To develop students' capacity for mathematical thinking necessary for the various issues and problems of social sciences
To teach basic concepts of logic, functions, probability and game theory
To teach the basics of quantitative techniques
To make students familiar with the basic data sets used in social sciences

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: This is an introductory macroeconomics course. The aim of the course is to teach elementary macroeconomic analysis and its applications. Among the main topics discussed are national income accounting, aggregate demand and supply, unemployment, money and inflation.
course_learning_outcomes: Calculate important macroeconomic economic concepts such a s the CPI or GDP
Explain economic cycles by the theories proposed by different schools of thought in economics
Explain unemployent through the labor market
Explain the effects of fiscal and monetary policies
Explain the relation between important economic concepts such as inflation rate, interest rate, unemployment rate etc

prepare a presentation to a specific audience
analyze an academic text
contextualizing an academic text
deliver a presentation to a specific audience

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The aim of this lecture is to teach any student who has finished its undergraduate studies, the Turkish language’s academic and literary verbalism features, reaching to a certain intellectual level that allows the student(s) to evaluate and discuss the teachings of such features, and learn the historical process of the literature that has been developed in this field.
course_learning_outcomes: Improving writing skills in Turkish language by learning the fundamental concepts and spelling rules.

Conceptualizing the written expressions in the Turkish language and acquiring the ability to understand the differences between the types of expression which will contribute to the skill set of the student(s).
Learning the basics of the written expressions, the ability to compare the written expression types and reflect this knowledge into personal work in the future.

Improving the ability of students who has finished their undergraduate studies to carry the knowledge in this class to professional and academic life, which will enable the individual to better itself in expressing, critical thinking and greatly distinguish itself in written command
Acquiring the ability of originality in thinking and demonstrating and analyzing the literary pieces with critical thinking abilities.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: Introduction to statistics with special emphasis on the utilization of statistical methods in social sciences: organization of data, measures of center and variability, basic probability concepts, descrete and continuous random variables and their distributions and inferences about the mean.
course_learning_outcomes: Upon successful completion of the course, the students become capable of reading, interpreting and making sense of the quantitative studies that they read in the social science literature.
The students become capable of making major calculations regarding central tendency and  variability.
The students learn how to make statistical analysis including regression and correlation.
The students will have a critical understanding of causality in social sciences
The students will have a general idea about the benefits and limitations of quantitative studies

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The course is designed to provide an introduction to Turkish Politics that aims to familiarize the student with the recent political history of Turkey and to develop a framework for analysis of contemporary Turkish politics.
course_learning_outcomes: The course is designed to provide an introduction to Turkish Politics that aims to familiarize the student with the recent political history of Turkey and to develop a framework for analysis of contemporary Turkish politics.

. The subject of the course covers the modernization process in the late Ottoman period, the establishment of the Turkish Republic, the single-party period, transition to the multi-party system, DP period and the review of political developments and political change until 1960.
•	Comprehend major developments in Turkish politics since the late Ottoman period with a specific focus on the political and economic modernization and Westernization
•	Describe the main characteristics of Turkey’s politics in the early Republican era and features of the and Kemalist nation building process and reforms.
•	Evaluate the decision on the transition to the multi-party rule in Turkey and discuss the characteristics of the Democrat Party with a specific focus on state-society relations.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: This course focuses on the developments that led to the end of the Cold War era and the politics of the post-Cold War period. Starting with the last decade of the Soviet Union and the forces that brought about the demise of Leninism in Eastern Europe, the break-up of Yugoslavia is studied as the paradigmatic case of the post-Cold War era. Other issues include the politics of the Middle East, post-Cold War American foreign policy and the pluses and minuses of globalization.
course_learning_outcomes: At the end of this course, the students should be able to possess factual and historical knowledge on contemporary world politics.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to identify the main issues and trends that effect world politics.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to reflect critically on the salient world political issues of the day.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to distinguish the proper venues through which they can follow salient world political developments.
At the end of this course, the students should be able to follow and comment on world political events over current social media platforms.

develop their English discussion skills.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The course will cover the republican period until the US occupation of Iraq in 2003. The lectures will emphasise major developments and discuss their reasons and consequences.
course_learning_outcomes: By the end of this course students will get background information about landmark developments of Turkey's foreign policy decisions taken during the period between 1920 and 2002.
Students would be able to identify the causes and effects of major developments on foreign policy decisions that the course will cover.
Students will understand the domestic political context of these decisions.
Students will understand the international context of these decisions.
Students will able to relate the concerning decisions with the current issues.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description:
The course introduces students to the study of social policy with a particular focus on
contemporary issues. Accordingly, the course aims to provide an understanding of
diverse ways in which welfare states have addressed social issues and the political
forces that have shaped these responses historically. Special emphasis is given to the
early writings and definition of social policy, the welfare state typologies, gendered
critique of the welfare state, social policy developments in Latin America and Asia and
responses to the new challenges and social risks.
course_learning_outcomes: Students will be able to describe the main theoretical discussions and approaches in social policy.
The students will have a familiarity with  the topics related to social policy (poverty, hunger, homelessness, health care, child labor, disabilities, educational inequality,  old-age).
Students will develop an understanding of the current issues of social policy and relate them to the theoretical and abstract concepts such as justice.
By conducting a research on one topic in the field, students will be able to reflect upon the major debates.
Students will be able to describe the historical development of welfare regime in Turkey and discuss its current status.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The course will cover current issues of Turkey’s foreign policy during the last decade. The lectures will deal with major international developments in the adjacent regions having particular relevance for Turkey's foreign policy agenda. The issues will be analysed through a three - İnternational system, national political and leadership- level analysis.
course_learning_outcomes: By the end of this course students will get information about important Turkish foreign policy decisions taken during the period succeeding 2003.
Students will be able to identify the causes and effects of developments surrounding the issues that the course will cover.
Students will understand the domestic political context of the issues and discuss the implications of the policies pursued by Ankara.
Students will be able to evaluate the background of the concerning decisions and put them into a internal political perspective.
Students will be able relate the concerning decisions to their historical precedents.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The course is designed to provide an introduction to Turkish Politics that aims to familiarize the student with the recent political history of Turkey and to develop a framework for analysis of contemporary Turkish politics.
course_learning_outcomes: The course is designed to provide an introduction to Turkish Politics that aims to familiarize the student with the recent political history of Turkey and to develop a framework for analysis of contemporary Turkish politics.

. The subject of the course covers the modernization process in the late Ottoman period, the establishment of the Turkish Republic, the single-party period, transition to the multi-party system, DP period and the review of political developments and political change until 1960.
•	Comprehend major developments in Turkish politics since the late Ottoman period with a specific focus on the political and economic modernization and Westernization
•	Describe the main characteristics of Turkey’s politics in the early Republican era and features of the and Kemalist nation building process and reforms.
•	Evaluate the decision on the transition to the multi-party rule in Turkey and discuss the characteristics of the Democrat Party with a specific focus on state-society relations.

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: The study of the political systems in a comparative framework enables students and scholars develop insight into the functioning of the regime and institutions in a country with a new perspective. This course introduces the basic concepts, institutions, and discussions of comparative politics, which will later be applied on the country cases in IR 302.
course_learning_outcomes: describe the basic concepts of International Relations and Political Science with comparative method
compare political systems and institutions
analyze the relation between the political institutions and democratic consolidation
analyze the impact of government systems and electoral institutions on the political systems
develop an analytical approach to political behavior from a comparative perspective

Political Science and Public Administrat.course_description: This course focuses on comparing the institutional composition of advanced industrialized democracies by building on the themes discussed in IR 101 (Introduction to Politics) and IR 301 (Comparative Politics I). The weeks are divided thematically, however the selection of readings aims to introduce students to the past and current political issues in Western Europe -especially in Britain, France, Germany- and in the USA, Russia, Mexico, China, Iran and Tunisia. The various decision-making institutions of these countries and how different configurations of power work in diverse political contexts will be analyzed. A variety of political party systems will be examined and the institutional, structural and historical causes of these divergent systems will be scrutinized.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand the significant elements of the presidential system in the USA and France.
Analyze the extent to which the parliaments in Britain, the USA, Germany and Russia keep the executive under control.
Compare the constitutional traditions of Britain and the USA.
Examine the party systems of Britain, the USA, France, Germany, and Spain.
Compare proportional representation and first-past-the-post electoral systems
Scrutinize how and why the single party regimes of Italy, Mexico, and Japan came to power.
Describe the basic institutional elements of the competitive authoritarian system in Russia.
Familiarize with the Indian and Chinese political systems' main frameworks.

Music.course_description:
This course explores the art of playing music together. Whether you’re a part of a duo, trio, quartet, small band, big
band, or orchestra, this course will help you form and maintain a powerful and productive music ensemble. You’ll
learn about the various aspects of being a part of an ensemble, including how it can enhance your musicianship and
what it takes away from you. By the end of this course, you’ll have gained valuable insights into the world of
ensemble playing and be better equipped to create and maintain successful musical collaborations.
course_learning_outcomes: Student develops the ability of playing together in a band.
Student understands the roles in the group and presents her/his/their instrument/voice as an individual voice in the band.
Student learns and applies multiplicity of listening modes.
Student develops the ability of improvising.
Student learns and experiences a variety of musical styles.

Music.course_description: This course is designed to help the students to improve their own musical intuitions. Students will develop every aspect of their musical abilities through intensive training in part writing, counterpoint, ear training and musical analysis. Musical examples of the course will be chosen from a wide range of western music history literature (pop songs, jazz and classical) to show the development of western music theory in history.

Apply basic notation rules.

Use musical scores and audio examples.

In this class, introductory level theoretical subjects will be applied to playing, with introductory level 2 hand pieces, chord accompanied melodies, scales and other technical exercises that support two hand coordination. 
Only Music Department students are accepted to this course.

Developing the ability of sight-reading for basic compositions written for two hands is aimed.

Music.course_description: The course will concentrate on the texts that illustrate conceptual frameworks corresponding to the music of the past as well as to the music of the 21st century. The focus will be on developing an analytical approach towards the topics of each class through critical reading, class discussion and weekly assignments. The texts will cover a broad range of topics from music history, musicology and music theory, as well as cultural studies, critical theory and sociology. The plan is to combine important analytical texts from the musical and sociological realms with historical documents to help students establish links between socio-economic conditions, philosophical concerns, the aesthetic spectrum and musical realities.
course_learning_outcomes: 1. Develop skills of critical and analytical thinking,
2. Develop reading, writing, listening and discussing skills.
3. Experience and try to overcome their shortcomings while discussing their arguments in a social environment,
4. Use library resource,
5. Discuss the texts written by the most important composers of modern music,
6. Define music and its position in a cultural context,
7. Define music, noise, sound and silence and the relationship between them.
8. Define performance, composition, listening and  recording and the relationship between them,

Music.course_description:
The course consists of a survey of music in its historical and social context, starting from ancient Greece through end of Baroque era and see how the development of music is related to social, political and economic developments of the era. Philosophical aspects of music will be discussed. Performance and compositional techniques will be analyzed as well as we will know prominent composers of the era. Extensive listening will take place in each lecture. Visual aids such as movies and slides will be used as well.
This course is only for the students of the Music Department.

This course studies stereo mastering process for music production. Technical tools and aesthetic

Music.course_description: This course aims to encourage students to discuss the current issues in music cognition. Students acquire knowledge about how we process musical data. Students will be introduced to how the brain processes audio streams and perceives musical structures. This course will cover topics like the perception of pitch, time, timbre, harmony, and musical space; auditory scene analysis, and perceptual grouping mechanisms.

Understand how brain analyzes auditory streams.
Explore various perceptual mechanisms of pitch, melody, rhythm, harmony, musical form, and emotion.
Understand relations between our sociocultural environment and cognitive mechanisms
Understand that music is a process in time that is actively created by the listener.

Music.course_description:

Describe melody, harmony, rhythm, meter, tempo, dynamics, articulation, texture and form.

The course consists of a survey of music in its historical and social context, starting from ancient Greece through end of Baroque era and see how the development of music is related to social, political and economic developments of the era. Identify the Major and minor tonality, diatonic chords and functions of the diatonic chords.

Music.course_description: In our cultural environment, a person receives very little explicit listening instruction and, as a result, tends to think of listening as passive rather than active behavior, failing to recognize the amount of effort and skill that it takes to be a good listener. This course focuses on the significance of listening and combines the knowledge of music theory and history to make students advance in their analytical skills.

Recognize the elements of music through listening to examples selected from various musical genres

Create new writing skills using the academic sources on World Music.

Students will be able to develop a critical point of view to the mainstream ways of presenting and conceiving of music

Music.course_description: In today’s music world it is important for a musician being up to date, aware of music business concepts and being able to deal with multiple operations in this business to catch the fast pace of the industry. This course aims to introduce the students the basic concepts of music business, new trends and hot topics in the music industry and most importantly give them a legal foundation so that they become fully equipped musicians.

Know musicians’ basic rights,
Be able to detect the problems that a musician can encounter and generate ideas to overcome those problems,
Understand the changes that the music industry goes through,
Analyze the relations of music industry and social dynamics through new media technologies.

Psychology.course_description: This course focus is on critical thinking and practice as it applies to the field of psychology. Using basic texts and theories from the field, the humanities and social sciences, students learn to apply and deepen their critical thinking skills in order to enhance their analytical understanding and prepare for their major in psychology.

Psychology.course_description: Contemporary psychology has evolved to study how people think, act and feel. This course will provide an introduction to major areas and topics in psychology, such as learning, memory, intelligence and motivation. The course will present an overview of major theoretical perspectives and research findings in psychology, and give evidence of how psychology works as a scientific process. The course will start with an introduction to the history of psychology and explore how it has developed as a scientific discipline over time. It will continue with an overview of the research methods used by psychologists and describe how scientific psychological studies are designed. It will focus on a set of topics related to various research areas in psychology, including cognitive, developmental, social and health psychology. Some of the topics that will be covered in the course are interactions between genetic and environmental factors in our development, processes of learning and remembering, intelligence and problem solving, theories of personality and motivation, and stress and well-being.
course_learning_outcomes: Define major psychological concepts and terms.
Describe and evaluate different perspectives and approaches in psychology.
Demonstrate an understanding of scientific methods (quantitative and qualitative) used in psychological studies.
Present examples of ground-breaking studies and theories in the basic and applied subfields of psychology.
Explain how biological, psychological and psychosocial factors interact and affect behaviors, attitudes, emotions, cognitions, and psychological well-being.
Characterize the nature of psychology as a discipline.
Demonstrate the ability to use psychological knowledge.

Psychology.course_description: A continuation of PSY 179. Psychology.course_description: This is the first part of a two-course sequence. Towards this end, students will be provided with the statistical skills required to collate, summarize, present and analyze data. Demonstrate facility in using English to discuss statistical analysis
Demonstrate an ability to recognize when to use statistical analysis.

Psychology.course_description: This course examines primary issues and methods of social science research. It covers basic aspects of the philosophy of science and main approaches to social research. All steps of planning and conducting a research (finding a research question, formulating hypotheses, selecting a design, selecting a sample, selecting instruments, composing a procedure, data collection, data analysis, and reporting) will be presented. This course aims to integrate the knowledge and skills acquired in the other researc-related courses such as Psychometrics and Statistics. Additionally, this course aims at providing the students with an opportunity to comprehend the relationship between theory and method.

Mastery of the statistical techniques most commonly used in the social sciences will be emphasized.

To understand and define the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.

Psychology.course_description: This course covers experimental methods in psychology including independent, repeated-measures and complex designs. Psychology.course_description: This is the first of a two-part sequence that offers a study of change and continuity in the physical, cognitive and psychosocial domains of human development from an ecological perspective. Psychology.course_description: This course is the second of a two-part sequence on social psychology (refer to PSY 201 above).
