Psychology.course_description: This course is desiged to give an overview of the field of industrial psychology and to help students develop a systems approach to understand the relationship between job design, organizational structure, employee competencies and productive and counterproductive human behaviors. It shows the tools and techniques to systematically investigate these behaviors and potential interventions related to them. This course will have "Classroom as Organizations" design. Students will work as small groups as if they are the members of a company's HRM department; i.e., a simulation study will be conducted. As initial step they will select a benchmark from a particular sector and company, they will invesgigate this organization and its HRM department. Their selected companies will be assumed to be part of a conglomerate where each student group will hold the responsibility to structure HRM department and realize major functions.
course_learning_outcomes: Describe human beings and their attributes as a resource in the organizational system.
Develop an understanding of the predictive value of competencies for productive and counterproductive behaviors.
Carry out a job and competency analysis.
Develop an understanding of the role of performance appraisal, training and development,  and compensation systems in the management of employee behaviors.
Show an understanding of the value and function of tools and methods developed by industrial psychologists in the human resources management departments and in overall organizational processes.
Develop an understanding of the challenges to industrial psychologists in getting a strategic role in organizational structures, as members of HRM departments and/or as independent consultants.

Sociology.course_description: This course aims to introduce first year sociology students to the basic concepts, problematics and approaches of sociology. The first part of the course critically considers the processes of production and consumption as they relate to modernity, specifically focusing on exploitative relations in various contexts. In thinking about past and present processes of production and commodification alongside patterns of consumption, students will develop a critical eye with which to evaluate and question their own practices and norms. Then, we move on to discussing sex, sexualities and gender, with an aim to discern and analyze taken-for-granted assumptions and the consequences thereby engendered in daily lives. This module ties into the previous one as students are urged to discuss issues related to the sexual division of labor and emotional labor. The third part of the course allows students to rethink the concepts of space and place as they relate to culture and lived experience. Following a theoretical discussion, students confront some major issues of urban sociology such as migration, segregation and policing. At the end of the semester, students are expected to reach a basic understanding of major sociological issues on which they will also have developed the skill to ask well-informed and thoughtful questions.
course_learning_outcomes: Develop a sociological vocabulary.
Improve basic scientific skills such as the ability to conceptualize, to contextualize, to problematize and to gain awareness of the social complexity.
Draw connections between the key sociological thoughts and contemporary social phenomena.
Develop sociological arguments based on theoretical and/or empirical materials.
Understand the concept of the society in historical context, along with its variations and transformations.

Sociology.course_description: This course aims to introduce the students to the culture and politics of modern Turkey through a historico-philosophical perspective. Beginning with the modernizing reforms of the late Ottoman Empire to the foundation and consolidation of the Turkish nation-state, it focuses on the birth, development, and culminating character of modern Turkey. Analyzing the main intellectual influences of Turkish political thought through primary and secondary sources and covering the important events, turning points, and historical figures of each decade of the Republican history, it aims to reveal the main historico-philosophical movements that have shaped Turkey’s political culture. Due to the interdisciplinary nature of the course, which extends to different fields such as politics, philosophy, science, art, and religion, the assigned readings are of a multidimensional and comprehensive nature. Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected to be able to comprehend the major turning points of Turkey’s political history and the movements, thinkers, and ideas that shaped it.
course_learning_outcomes: The student can differentiate between one-party regime and multi-party politics.
The student can express causes and consequences of military interventions in Turkey.
The student can hold a simple but informed debate about Turkish politics in social occasions.
Student can evaluate on Turkish within the line of democratization.
Student can think about Turkish politics within the developments in international conjuncture.

Sociology.course_description: English for Academic Purposes I is a course designed to develop the academic language and academic skills needed by students in order to be successful in their respective departments. Students will be guided through the various stages of writing, including planning, researching and collecting and organizing information. Students will be working with semi-authentic to authentic academic texts. The course aims to introduce efficient reading strategies to cope with such texts as well as to increase students' confidence and comprehensibility when delivering information in an academic setting. Academic writing, listening, speaking and reading skills development will be emphasized in the course. Additionally, students' skills in test-taking, paraphrasing, summarizing and note-taking will be developed.
course_learning_outcomes: recognize vocabulary and discern meaning from context
analyze a text
contextualize an academic text
summarize a text in a written format
write a reflection

Sociology.course_description:
The aim of this lecture is to teach any student who has finished its undergraduate studies, to acknowledge and learn the structure and the functionality of the Turkish language, from the perspective of linguistic and thought relation, to implement the skill to use the Turkish language right and effective as a written and spoken expression tool.
By teaching the historical process of the Turkish language, its place in the universal linguistic families, analyzing the important shifts and transformations of the Turkish language, and carefully teaching the sets of dictation, this lecture is set to transpose an overall knowledge and practical skill sets to students.
course_learning_outcomes: Understanding the fundamental concepts of the Turkish language, its historical process, and the ability to reflect these learnings in daily life.

Establishing the skill to understand the main takeaways of this course and further use these capacities to compare the Turkish language with other languages, detecting puzzles and issues within this comparison and address rational responses to such problems.

Learning the structural and conceptual aspects of the Turkish language, improving overall knowledge about the language for better evaluation and analysis, and to attain the ability to do accurate research and rational answers when being questioned about this field.

Learning the unique relationship of the language with other disciplines which will contribute greatly to the intellectual accumulation of the student(s) to use the language with awareness and originality.
To care about the oral and written set of rules of the Turkish language and raising awareness.

Sociology.course_description: This course is intended as a semester-long exercise in getting first year sociology students to hit the streets of Istanbul with a view as to expose them to the practices and workings of the urban everyday – past and present. This course will require students to spend every other session in the “field” and thus learn about and through the city’s various sites and sensations. The field trips will allow them to investigate the city’s lifelines mainly through economic and historical lenses and to adopt a critical and reflective gaze in regards to dynamics they may previously have overlooked. The fieldtrips will be followed by in-class reflection sessions designed to incite discussion and analysis. By the end of the semester, the students will have reached a deeper, more nuanced and more complex understanding of Istanbul and its social, historical and economic undercurrents and they will have acquired the tools necessary to determine and engage with social problematics, tying in their hands-on experience with theoretical formulations in their other courses.
course_learning_outcomes: identify the economic and historical lifelines of the city.
develop a more complex understanding of the urban based on their field encounters with sociological reality.
develop the skills “to sociologically see” and thus evaluate various social dynamics
critically reflect on the everyday both orally and in writing.
get to know some practices to map the theoretical inferences and insights they discuss in other courses.

Sociology.course_description: This course is intended as a way for students to critically engage with the concepts of modernization and development as conflated with Westernization and the racist implications of this imagination. We begin with a critical discussion of modernization, studying it in theory and through case studies, and later engage theoretically with the concept of race as it pertains to notions of civilization, policing, passing and intersectionality drawing on cases from around the world. Then, we switch the focus to Turkey to think through modernization and Westernization vis-à-vis Orientalism, citizenship, ethnicity, race and gender. The goal of this course is to offer students ways in which to critically reflect on the society in which they live, particularly taking note of how grand narratives and everyday experiences influence and feed off each other.
course_learning_outcomes: Effectively employ sociological imagination to ask questions about the social world and devise critical answers
Critically engage with the concepts of modernization and development
Parse out the main argument of an academic article, how the argument is constructed and how it relates to broader issues in society
Engage theoretically with the concept of race as it pertains to notions of civilization, policing, passing and intersectionality
Focus on Turkey to think through modernization and Westernization ethnicity and race
Focus on Turkey to think through modernization and Westernization vis-à-vis Orientalism and Occidentalism
Focus on Turkey to think through citizenship and nationalism as gendered

Sociology.course_description: This course is the second of a two-semester overview of global history that examines pivotal encounters, exchanges and conflicts between cultures and civilizations that profoundly influenced the course of human history. We selectively cover the various regions of Asia, Africa, Europe, the Middle East and the Americas while looking at major global processes such as migration, trade and the spread of religion. These global processes are contextualized within major historical developments such as the formation and dissolution of states and empires. HIST 161 begins with ancient trade networks of the Fertile Crescent to the spread of monotheism in late antiquity and the early Middle Ages, through Columbus' arrival in the Americas in 1492. HIST 162 continues from the 16th century until the Second World War, covering major developments including the rise of the Atlantic trade system, industrialization, modernization, the emergence of the nation-states, colonialism, the Russian revolution and the rise of fascism.
course_learning_outcomes: understand industrialization
understand political and economic revolutions
grasp the emergence of nationalisms
describe colonization
explain the rise of global capitalism

Sociology.course_description: In this course, the conception of rationality peculiar to modernity will be examined in the light of the works of such philosophers as Descartes, Locke, Leibniz, Hume and Kant. The limits and problems of the new meaning, significance and function acquired by philosophy in this period will be discussed and the new conception of rationality adopted by modernity will be submitted to a critical analysis from the perspective described above.
course_learning_outcomes: Demonstrate and apply the fundamental abilites required to read, comprehend, interpret, analyze and critically evaluate philosophical texts.
Identify the meaning, significance, and function of philosophy in modern thought.
Explain, compare and evaluate the fundamental philosophical debates of this period and present a conceptual and historical analysis of these discussions.
Evaluate the dynamics and specificity of a early modern philosophy in terms of its continiuities and discontinuities with regard to preceding and following periods.
Distinguish the status and impact of philosophy in the development of modern thought.

Sociology.course_description: English for Academic Purposes II is a course designed to further develop and expand upon the academic language skills needed by students in order to be successful in their academic departments. Students will be guided through the various stages of writing, including planning, researching and collecting and organizing information. Students will be working with semi-authentic to authentic academic texts. The course aims to introduce efficient reading strategies to cope with such texts as well as to increase students' confidence and comprehensibility when delivering information in an academic setting. Academic writing, listening, speaking and reading skills development will be emphasized in the course. Additionally, students' skills in paraphrasing, summarizing and note-taking will be further developed.
course_learning_outcomes: determine research skills and strategies
apply research skills and strategies
deliver a presentation to a specific audience
participate in discussions concerning topics studied in class
write a problem essay

Sociology.course_description: The aim of this lecture is to teach any student who has finished its undergraduate studies, the Turkish language’s academic and literary verbalism features, reaching to a certain intellectual level that allows the student(s) to evaluate and discuss the teachings of such features, and learn the historical process of the literature that has been developed in this field.
course_learning_outcomes: Improving writing skills in Turkish language by learning the fundamental concepts and spelling rules.

Conceptualizing the written expressions in the Turkish language and acquiring the ability to understand the differences between the types of expression which will contribute to the skill set of the student(s).
Learning the basics of the written expressions, the ability to compare the written expression types and reflect this knowledge into personal work in the future.

Improving the ability of students who has finished their undergraduate studies to carry the knowledge in this class to professional and academic life, which will enable the individual to better itself in expressing, critical thinking and greatly distinguish itself in written command
Acquiring the ability of originality in thinking and demonstrating and analyzing the literary pieces with critical thinking abilities.

Sociology.course_description: The course examines main issues and methods of social science research. It covers basic aspects of the philosophy of science, the logic of scientific inquiry, methodological traditions and the main approaches to and the main techniques and methods of social research. A wide range of research methods, both quantitative and qualitative, that social scientists employ in attempting to understand the social world are described and evaluated. The course provides students with an understanding of the relationship between theory and method.
course_learning_outcomes: Identify key issues and developments in the philosophy of social science
Develop a basic comprehension of ontological and epistemological approaches in sociology
Assess the strengths and weaknesses of alternative research techniques
Develop an understanding of the practical aspects of conducting research
Develop an awareness of the ethical issues surrounding social research

Sociology.course_description: This course handles the ideological, economic, social and cultural changes in Turkey, focusing on the early Republican and the multi-party periods. The changes that took place in the transition from the empire to the nation state are discussed in relation with major issues of everyday life. The course focuses on themes such as the Ottoman legacy, modernization debates, the turkification of the economy, labor, migration, urbanization, housing, gender, body and music.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
*develop a sociological understanding of changes in contemporary Turkish society
*adapt a historical perspective to understand socio-cultural problems in Turkey
*reflect on major social changes in in early 20th century Turkey
*evaluate social changes and transformations in Turkey by using concepts of civil society and public sphere
*interpret the ruptures and continuities from the Ottoman empire to the Turkish Republic

Sociology.course_description: This course is intended to introduce students to the basic concepts, theories and methodologies of cultural anthropology. The course is divided into two parts. The first part is designed as a way to introduce students to the field of cultural anthropology by discussing its foundations, historical trajectory, main problematics and methods. The first 6 weeks will thus allow students to arrive at a nuanced and well thoroughly thoughtful engagement with the concept of culture, the intricacies of fieldwork and certain political stakes involved in current anthropological analyses. The second part of the course is dedicated to exploring some of the main areas of study within cultural anthropology including kinship, medicine, language, economics, and politics. With each of these concentrations we will focus on how power hierarchies on various scales implicate relations at times assumed to be independent from cultural and thus political influence. The goal of the course is to equip students with the tools necessary to challenge their preconceptions about social processes. Students will be encouraged to shed deeply entrenched notions and assumptions about societies around the world as well as their own, gaining a sense of anthropology as an unending self-reflexive attitude.
course_learning_outcomes: have a well-rounded knowledge of the discipline of anthropology, including its historical trajectory, basic concepts and methods.
comprehend the approaches of medical, economic, linguistic and legal anthropology.
understand the intricacies of fieldwork in anthropology, including questions that pertain to hierarchies in the field, ethics and self-reflexivity.
critically engage with the concept of culture especially vis-a-vis power and politics.
conjure an anthropological research project.
take everyday instances and analyze them through the lens of social and cultural anthropology
will have a well-informed sense of how the discipline has historically evolved and how it situates within the larger social sciences

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to develop a solid understanding of the intellectual origins of sociology. It examines sociological theory, schools of thought and individual theorists from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and their influence in the emergence of major contemporary theoretical perspectives. The course systematically and critically analyzes classical sociological theories, locating them in their philosophical and historical contexts and emphasizing their relevance for the analysis of contemporary societies and their contribution to the contemporary configuration of social thought.
course_learning_outcomes: To identify the main currents and themes of classical sociological theory
To explain the major contributions of canonical figures in the history of sociological thought
To understand some of the major problems and limitations of classical theories
To relate sociological theory to broad socio-historical develoments
To develop skills in writing reaction papers on key sociological terms

Sociology.course_description: HTR 111, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims teaching some terms like social science, history, revolution, counter-revolution, coups d’etat, state, political power, authority, law, rights etc. The module also aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman society, which is important to understand the conditions of Turkish Revolution. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To discuss some terms like "social science", "history", "revolution", "coups d'etat", "state", "political power", "authority", "law", "rights" etc.
To understand what the political, social and economic structure of Ottoman Empire was
To understand the differences between Ottoman land formation and feudalism.
To understand what Ottoman modernization was.
To discuss what Ottoman modernization was.

Sociology.course_description: This course is intended as a way for undergraduate students to consolidate and carry further their engagement with the foremost methods of social research. The course offers a nuanced engagement with the concept of “mixed methods,” allowing students to discern the advantages as well as the drawbacks of how diverse methods and methodological approaches can be used together. The semester starts with a brief recap of research basics delving into the question of how data and theory are to relate with each other. The first part also includes an in-depth engagement with how research questions are formulated and the main concepts regarding measurement and sampling. This part ends with critical engagement with “quantification” allowing students, once again, to carefully consider and delineate cognizant applications of “mixed methods.” The second part of the course is divided into three subsections entitled “Learn, Discern and Apply” whereby students are expected to read about, diagnose and practice specific research methods and their tools such as survey research, observation, and interviews. Each of these sections is designed to immerse students in the “making” of research and its intricately messy “kitchen.” The semester ends with a final consideration of discourse and narrative analysis so as to enrich the components of how we might gauge mixed methods. Overall, the aim of this course is to impart an in-depth understanding of methods, the design and application of foremost tools and how variant tools and approaches may be used in tandem with each other in thoughtful and sophisticated ways.
course_learning_outcomes: Grasp depths of knowledge re: main concepts and issues in research.
Engage in an in-depth fashion with debates surrounding the use of mixed methods research.
Discern and practice various different research methods.
Evaluate thoughtfully the relation between data, theory and application which can allow them to engage in learned implementations of relevant approaches.
Draft a research proposal.

Sociology.course_description: The course explores some of the current "hot topics" in sociology as well as broad theoretical perspectives and examines their contribution to theories of social change, social stratification, power and globalization. It aims to enable students to apply sociological knowledge and thinking to a range of social issues and debates at local, national and global levels. Students are provided with an understanding of modern conceptions of social reality. Current sociological debates with respect to topics such as identity, ethnicity, imagined communities, cultural diversity, state and civil society, social movements, modernization and globalization are examined.
course_learning_outcomes: To develop and understanding of different sociological perspectives on key issues such nationalism, militarism, sexism, identity claims and social movements in Turkey,
To identify key concepts relating prejudice, stereotype and discrimination
To explore and evaluate theories of discrimination
To identify various types of discrimination and human rights violations
To acquire an awareness of social and political contexts leading to discrimination
To report discriminatory utterances and human rights violations in a written text
To apply methods of text analysis and discourse analysis

Sociology.course_description: In this course, the works of two significant theorists are read in depth. First, we focus on the concepts and selected works of Pierre Bourdieu. Then we continue with the selected works of Michel Foucault. Written sources are backed with podcasts and documentaries about these two theorists.
course_learning_outcomes: Link contemporary social theorists and their ideas to some current social problems.
Apply theoretical concepts to real-life phenomena.
Enhance their vocabulary and conceptual knowledge.
Learn working through hard texts and difficult ideas.
Identify the diversity of perspectives in contemporary sociological thought.

Sociology.course_description: HTR 112, which is necessary to graduate from the university for all students, aims to accelerate students’ knowledge about the conditions of Turkish national war and Turkish revolution and foundation of Modern Turkish Republic. In addition, it is aimed to improve students’ views about the history critically and to know different perspectives about the historical events.
course_learning_outcomes: To understand the reasons of the Turkish National War, to define the Turkish National War
To compare Sevres Treaty and Lozan Treaty.
To understand and define the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To understand political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.
To discuss political and social change after the foundation of modern Turkish Republic.

Sociology.course_description: This course aims to provide students with the necessary statistical skills required to collate, summarize, present and analyze data. It provides students with the necessary tools for handling and understanding empirical studies in the social sciences.
course_learning_outcomes: Demonstrate the ability to read statistical tables
Demonstrate mathematical precision when performing calculations;
Demonstrate facility to discuss statistical analysis
Increase basic knowledge level of students about statistics
Demonstrate the ability to interpret statistical tables

Sociology.course_description: This course aims to introduce students to sociological perspectives on economic phenomena. We will start with overviews of classical and contemporary approaches to economic sociology. We then focus on two major theorists, Karl Polanyi and Viviana Zelizer, for a historical understanding of "the place of the economy in society" and the relationships between the markets and societies. We will continue exploring a different aspect of the economy each week, such as "gig" work, consumption trends, bodily commodification, domestic care work, household debt, etc. By exploring such diverse topics, we aim to understand how economic life is shaped by social structures, cultural values and power.
course_learning_outcomes: to understand major classical and contemporary theoretical perspectives in the field of economic sociology
to recognize major aspects of the economic life in contemporary societies
to draw on theorists such as Karl Polanyi, Mark Granovetter and Viviana Zelizer to interpret contemporary studies in the field of economic sociology
to interpret descriptive statistical data on contemporary economies
to use socio-economic perspectives and data for understanding the social aspects of economic problems in Turkey

Sociology.course_description: The course is based on the study of structured social inequalities. Discussion focuses on the classical theories of social stratification, class and social mobility and on recent contributions to the ongoing debate in the field. With regard to the post-industrial world, focus is placed on both the persistence (or not) of social class as an empirical phenomenon and its relevance as an analytic tool for understanding societies. Empirical studies of social inequality in various societies, notably in Turkey, are considered within the framework of changing theoretical issues on gender, race, ethnicity, and health.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will (be able to): 

develop an understanding of the key elements and effects of social stratification and social inequality,
identify the main theoretical approaches to social stratification
develop comprehension of changes in social stratification and social inequality
identify main themes and issues on poverty with a specific focus on Turkish case
develop an understanding of global stratification system and make connections between global and national (Turkish) stratification systems
analyze Turkish society from the perspective of social inequality
relate empirical research on poverty to broader theoretical approaches of stratification
implement field research on poverty

Sociology.course_description: This course will cover the texts of major figures in the field of structuralist and post-structuralist thought and philosophy beginning with the pioneering work of Saussure. After outlining the contributions of structuralism, the course will move on to the discussions of different accounts of discourse, subjectivity, representation, postmodernity, sexual subjectivitypower, the meaning of the social and otherness.
course_learning_outcomes: Develop their skills of enquiry and critical evaluation of the interconnections between philosophy and social sciences.
Improve the cognitive and communicative skills as well as enhance their ability to read, analyze, discuss, write and think critically on contemporary social theory.
Develop general sociological skills for comprehending contemporary social, political and cultural processes of our globalized world.
Recognize and appreciate the importance of interdisciplinary thinking for sociological analysis
Identify diversity of theoretical approaches in major contemporary sociological thought.

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to provide students with a comparative and historical overview of the nature, causes and consequences of urbanization. Conceptual debates and major social theoretical perspectives on urban development are critically reviewed. Issues and debates in contemporary urban sociology are explored. Focus is upon the process of urbanization and an analysis of cities, urban behavior patterns, urban riots, social relationships and urban problems.
course_learning_outcomes: To develop an understanding of major theories of urbanization
To analyze the origins and changing patterns of urbanization in the world and in Turkey
To identify key sociological terms relating urban sociology
To identify key issues and debates in contemporary urban sociology
To analyze the nature of urban behavior patterns, social relationships and urban problems
To apply sociological theory and empirical research in the field of urban sociology

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to familiarize students with the basic themes and research agendas in the field of political sociology. After a general coverage of the debates related to power and the origins of the modern state, topics such as types of political regimes, the interaction between the state and society, the significance of social movements and the  role of the state in the process of globalization are discussed and in this context the changing definitions of politics and power are emphasized, and the consequences of digital revolution and dataism are evaluated.
course_learning_outcomes: Understand the contemporary debates and issues in political sociology
Gain knowledge about the concept of power
Identify basic types of political regimes
Evaluate the relation between the state and civil society
Define the relationship between the politics and economy
Evaluate the effects of globalization and changing technology on society and politics.

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to provide students with a gender perspective in the study of the family and awareness of gender in the study of all social relationships. Conceptual debates and major social theoretical perspectives on family and gender will be critically reviewed. A historical and cross-cultural study of gender roles, statuses and identities as well as gender relations will be examined.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will (be able to):

identify the biological, social and cultural references of the constructions of femininity and masculinity,
explain the processes through which gender is socially constructed,
develop basic comprehension of different theoretical perspectives for the analysis of gender
relate different constructions of femininity and masculinity to wider social structures,
identify different presentations and experiences of gender in society,
evaluate gender and family relations in the context of local and global historical transformations,
follow the sociological, psychoanalytical and historical debates concerning the gender and family relations,
understand the transformations put forward by feminist theory and movement regarding gender and family relations in a historical context.

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to provide students with a general understanding of the role of culture in the constitution of social life and identities. It introduces students to key debates on the meaning of culture and explores the ways in which sociologists and cultural critics have approached the study of culture. The relationship between culture consumption and identity, the concepts of high and folk culture and the debate over postmodernism and cultural populism are critically examined.
course_learning_outcomes: Identify the essential sociological debates on culture.
Investigate the key concepts of culture such as modernity, postmodernity and hegemony.
Explore anti-systemic movements and social mobilizations.
Evaluate the significance of popular culture in everyday life and its contestations.
Understand the nature of meaning-making in a globalizing cultural setting.

Sociology.course_description: The course introduces students to the major currents and central concepts of Ottoman-Turkish social thought from the classical age up to the twentieth century. It systematically and critically analyzes the theories, central ideas and arguments of major intellectual figures, locating them in their philosophical and historical contexts and identifying their intellectual roots.
course_learning_outcomes: Identify major currents of Otoman social and political thought
Discuss the change in Otoman perceptions of the West
Analyze major theoretical perspectives in their social and historical contexts
Critically evaluate the theories, central ideas, and arguments of major intellectual figures
Evaluate the legacy of Otoman social thought on modern Turkey

Sociology.course_description: This course is designed to make the students familiar with the main topics and discussions in the field of historical sociology. Firstly, the history of the historical sociology is focused to see how the relation between the disciplines of history and sociology has evolved and what kind of discussions have been made about theory and methodology. Another aim of the course is to study some major works in the field to see different approaches and concerns by some major scholars. Here, the issues of civilization, state, revolution, citizenship, and capitalist development are especially explored in order to understand the historical foundations of contemporary societies. Besides these topics, attention will also be paid to theoretical debates on understanding the origins, continuity, and change of social institutions.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
explain the relation and interaction between the disciplines of history and sociology
identify key issues in the field of historical sociology
identify major epistemological/methodological issues in the field
gain comprehension of issues relating to a specific historical period and/or geography in historical sociological terms
write a research paper on a topic in historical sociology

Sociology.course_description: This course provides an introduction to the key topics in medical sociology, focusing on the social dimensions of health, illness, health care, and medical practice in modern societies. Through an examination of research and theories, we will delve into the complex interactions between health professionals and service users in specific organizational contexts. We will also explore the influence of cultural environments on perceptions of health, disease, and medical interventions, as well as the commodification of health care in medical markets. Additionally, we will cover the production of medical knowledge and technologies, the relationship between social inequalities and health disparities, and the role of social movements in challenging expert authority and health policy. Furthermore, we will discuss the ways in which individuals' bodies and selves are transformed by illness and medical intervention. While our research examples will encompass diverse global contexts, a special emphasis will be placed on the socio-medical landscape of contemporary Turkey.
course_learning_outcomes: grasp the major classical and contemporary theoretical perspectives in the field of medical sociology
to recognize the major aspects of health, illness, and medical practices in contemporary societies
to draw on major theorists from the field of medical sociology such as Conrad, Clarke, Rose, and Timmermans to interpret contemporary issues concerning health, illness, and medicine
use their skills to examine the social aspects of major issues concerning the Turkish healthcare sector and the medical field
use quantitative and qualitative data about health, illness and medicine in contemporary societies

Sociology.course_description: This course focuses on some salient names and underlying currents of social & political thought in twentieth century Turkey. Each social/political thinker is investigated with special reference to the history of republican Turkey and his life course. Through the personality of these figures various thoughts and ideologies such as Kemalism, nationalism, İslamism, conservatism, liberalism, socialism in contemporary Turkey are examined.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
*understand the historical, social and political contexts of some major social thinkers in Republican Turkey.
*evaluate the unfolding of social and political thought starting from Ziya Gökalp to post-1980 intellectual developments.
*articulate the intersecting points and also polarizations among the political movements such as Islamism, Kemalism, Turkism, nationalism, conservatism, and leftist thinking.
*recognize the relation between thoughts and life stories of some important names in the intellectual history of the Republic.
*analyze the change in the political and social thought in the post-1980 period.

Sociology.course_description: This course aims to explore the social aspects of algorithms and artificial intelligence (AI) enabled technologies. We will examine the ways in which algorithms and AI-enabled technologies shape social life, considering their intended and unintended consequences. We will also examine the ways in which technological innovation in AI industry may be shaped by social norms, needs, and power relations. We start the course with a brief account of theoretical perspectives on the place of science and technology in society. We continue focusing on algorithms and AI-enabled technologies, focusing on specific themes such as the following: algorithmic bias; Big Data; surveillance capitalism; robotics & digital automation; algorithmic management in the working life; the future of work, the regulation of AI industry, etc.
course_learning_outcomes: have knowledge about the social aspects of algorithms and AI-enabled technologies.
see the links between technological developments and the social forces.
be equipped with the sociological perspectives on the major AI advances.
have knowledge about the use of algorithms, artificial intelligence and automation technologies in different areas of social life.
detect what kind of social, political and ethical problems AI-enabled technologies can pose for societies.

Sociology.course_description: This introductory course aims to provide students with a general understanding of sociological themes and concepts and the ability to appreciate the differences between sociological and common-sense ways of thinking about the social world. It enables students to understand the major theoretical models that can be brought to bear in the analysis of social structure, social divisions, social processes and institutions and the significance of current sociological theories, research and debates around the changing nature of contemporary societies.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of the course the student will (be able to):

develop comprehension of basic concepts of sociology,
understand how social structures play crucial roles in shaping our experiences,
identify the main social issues shaping contemporary societies,
develop a sociological perspective vis-a-vis social problems,
think critically about the latest sociological debates.

Sociology.course_description: This course handles the ideological, economic, social and cultural changes in Turkey, focusing on the early Republican and the multi-party periods. The changes that took place in the transition from the empire to the nation state are discussed in relation with major issues of everyday life. The course focuses on themes such as the Ottoman legacy, modernization debates, the turkification of the economy, labor, migration, urbanization, housing, gender, body and music.

On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
*develop a sociological understanding of changes in contemporary Turkish society
*adapt a historical perspective to understand socio-cultural problems in Turkey
*reflect on major social changes in in early 20th century Turkey
*evaluate social changes and transformations in Turkey by using concepts of civil society and public sphere
*interpret the ruptures and continuities from the Ottoman empire to the Turkish Republic

It examines sociological theory, schools of thought and individual theorists from the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries and their influence in the emergence of major contemporary theoretical perspectives. The course systematically and critically analyzes classical sociological theories, locating them in their philosophical and historical contexts and emphasizing their relevance for the analysis of contemporary societies and their contribution to the contemporary configuration of social thought.

To explain the major contributions of canonical figures in the history of sociological thought
To understand some of the major problems and limitations of classical theories
To relate sociological theory to broad socio-historical develoments
To develop skills in writing reaction papers on key sociological terms

To identify key concepts relating prejudice, stereotype and discrimination

Sociology.course_description: The course aims to provide students with a comparative and historical overview of the nature, causes and consequences of urbanization. Conceptual debates and major social theoretical perspectives on urban development are critically reviewed. Issues and debates in contemporary urban sociology are explored. Focus is upon the process of urbanization and an analysis of cities, urban behavior patterns, urban riots, social relationships and urban problems.
course_learning_outcomes: To develop an understanding of major theories of urbanization
To analyze the origins and changing patterns of urbanization in the world and in Turkey
To identify key sociological terms relating urban sociology
To identify key issues and debates in contemporary urban sociology
To analyze the nature of urban behavior patterns, social relationships and urban problems
To apply sociological theory and empirical research in the field of urban sociology

Sociology.course_description: In this course, the works of two significant theorists are read in depth. First, we focus on the concepts and selected works of Pierre Bourdieu. Then we continue with the selected works of Michel Foucault. Written sources are backed with podcasts and documentaries about these two theorists.
course_learning_outcomes: Link contemporary social theorists and their ideas to some current social problems.
Apply theoretical concepts to real-life phenomena.
Enhance their vocabulary and conceptual knowledge.
Learn working through hard texts and difficult ideas.
Identify the diversity of perspectives in contemporary sociological thought.

Sociology.course_description: The course is based on the study of structured social inequalities. Discussion focuses on the classical theories of social stratification, class and social mobility and on recent contributions to the ongoing debate in the field. With regard to the post-industrial world, focus is placed on both the persistence (or not) of social class as an empirical phenomenon and its relevance as an analytic tool for understanding societies. Empirical studies of social inequality in various societies, notably in Turkey, are considered within the framework of changing theoretical issues on gender, race, ethnicity, and health.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will (be able to): 

develop an understanding of the key elements and effects of social stratification and social inequality,
identify the main theoretical approaches to social stratification
develop comprehension of changes in social stratification and social inequality
identify main themes and issues on poverty with a specific focus on Turkish case
develop an understanding of global stratification system and make connections between global and national (Turkish) stratification systems
analyze Turkish society from the perspective of social inequality
relate empirical research on poverty to broader theoretical approaches of stratification
implement field research on poverty

Sociology.course_description: This course focuses on some salient names and underlying currents of social & political thought in twentieth century Turkey. Each social/political thinker is investigated with special reference to the history of republican Turkey and his life course. Through the personality of these figures various thoughts and ideologies such as Kemalism, nationalism, İslamism, conservatism, liberalism, socialism in contemporary Turkey are examined.
course_learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this course, students will be able to:
*understand the historical, social and political contexts of some major social thinkers in Republican Turkey.
*evaluate the unfolding of social and political thought starting from Ziya Gökalp to post-1980 intellectual developments.
*articulate the intersecting points and also polarizations among the political movements such as Islamism, Kemalism, Turkism, nationalism, conservatism, and leftist thinking.
*recognize the relation between thoughts and life stories of some important names in the intellectual history of the Republic.
*analyze the change in the political and social thought in the post-1980 period.
